Part I Matrix & vector calculus

The exercises about Matrix & vector calculus are optional and can be skipped.
Exercise 1. ( ★ )
Let A,B be K × K invertible matrices . Show that (A+B ) -1 = A -1 ( A -1 + B -1 ) -1 B -1
Solution. It is (A+B ) -1 = A -1 (I+ A -1 B ) -1 = A -1 ( A -1 + B -1 ) -1 B -1
Exercise 2. ( ★ ★ )
[Woodbury matrix identity] Verify that ( A+UCV ) -1 = A -1 - A -1 U ( C -1 +V A -1 U ) -1 V A -1 if A and C are non-singular.
Solution.  
By checking that ( A+UCV ) ( A+UCV ) -1 =I ( A+UCV ) × [ A -1 - A -1 U ( C -1 +V A -1 U ) -1 V A -1 ] =I+UCV A -1 -( U+UCV A -1 U ) ( C -1 +V A -1 U ) -1 V A -1 =I+UCV A -1 -UC( C -1 +V A -1 U ) ( C -1 +V A -1 U ) -1 V A -1 =I+UCV A -1 -UCV A -1 =I. So ( A+UCV ) -1 = A -1 - A -1 U ( C -1 +V A -1 U ) -1 V A -1
Exercise 3. ( ★ ★ )
[Sherman–Morrison formula] Let A be a K × K invertible matrix and u and v two K × 1 column vectors. Verify that ( A+u v ⊤ ) -1 = A -1 - 1 1+ v ⊤ A -1 u A -1 u v ⊤ A -1 if 1+ v ⊤ A -1 u ≠ 0 , and if A is non-singular.
Solution.  
( A+u v T ) (A+u v T ) -1 =( A+u v T ) ( A -1 - A -1 u v T A -1 1+ v T A -1 u ) =A A -1 +u v T A -1 - A A -1 u v T A -1 +u v T A -1 u v T A -1 1+ v T A -1 u =I+u v T A -1 - u v T A -1 +u v T A -1 u v T A -1 1+ v T A -1 u =I+u v T A -1 - u( 1+ v T A -1 u ) v T A -1 1+ v T A -1 u =I+u v T A -1 -u v T A -1 =I
Exercise 4. ( ★ ★ ★ )
[Block partition matrix inversion] Let A be K × K invertible matrix, and let B= A -1 its inverse. Consider Partition A=[ A 11 A 12 A 21 A 22 ];B=[ B 11 B 12 B 21 B 22 ] Namely, B 11 = [ A -1 ] 11 is the upper corner of the A -1 , etc...
Show that A 11 -1 = B 11 = B 12 B 22 -1 B 21 A 11 -1 A 12 =- B 12 B 22 -1
Hint:
Start by noticing that AB=I ⟺ [ A 11 A 12 A 21 A 22 ][ B 11 B 12 B 21 B 22 ]=[ I 0 0 I ] ⟺ { A 11 B 11 + A 12 B 21 =I A 11 B 12 + A 12 B 22 =0
Solution. It is AB=I ⟺ [ A 11 A 12 A 21 A 22 ][ B 11 B 12 B 21 B 22 ]=[ I 0 0 I ] ⟺ { A 11 B 11 + A 12 B 21 =I A 11 B 12 + A 12 B 22 =0 So A 11 B 12 + A 12 B 22 =0 ⟺ A 11 -1 ( A 11 B 12 + A 12 B 22 ) B 22 -1 =0 ⟺ B 12 B 22 -1 + A 11 -1 A 12 =0 So A 11 -1 A 12 =- B 12 B 22 -1 Also A 11 B 12 + A 12 B 22 =0 ⟺ ( A 11 B 12 + A 12 B 22 ) B 22 -1 B 21 =0 ⟺ A 11 B 12 B 22 -1 B 21 + A 12 B 21 =0 A 12 B 21 =- A 11 B 12 B 22 -1 B 21 Then, we plug in the above in A 11 B 11 + A 12 B 21 =I we get A 11 B 11 + A 12 B 21 =I ⟺ A 11 B 11 - A 11 B 12 B 22 -1 B 21 =I ⟺ B 11 - B 12 B 22 -1 B 21 = A 11 -1 So A 11 -1 = B 11 = B 12 B 22 -1 B 21

Part II Random variables

Exercise 5. ( ★ )
Let y ∈ Y ⊆ R be a univariate random variable with CDF F y ( ⋅ ) . Consider a bijective function h: Y → Z with z=h( y ) , and h -1 its inverse. The PDF of z is F z ( z ) ={ F Y ( h -1 ( z ) ) if  h nnearrow 1- F Y ( h -1 ( z ) ) if  h ssearrow
Solution.  It is z=h( y ) ↔ y= h -1 ( z )
For if  h nnearrow it is F z ( z ) = P ( Z ≤ z ) = P ( h -1 ( Z ) ≤ h -1 ( z ) ) = P ( Y ≤ h -1 ( z ) ) = F Y ( h -1 ( z ) ) For if  h ssearrow it is F z ( z ) = P ( Z ≤ z ) = P ( h -1 ( Z ) ≥ h -1 ( z ) ) = P ( Y ≥ h -1 ( z ) ) =1- F Y ( h -1 ( z ) )
Exercise 6. ( ★ )
Let y ∈ Y ⊆ R be a univariate random variable with PDF f y ( ⋅ ) . Consider a bijective function h: Y → Z ⊆ R and let h -1 be the inverse function of h . Consider a univariate random variable such that z=h( y ) . The PDF of z is f z ( z ) = f y ( y ) | det ( d y d z ) |= f y ( h -1 ( z ) ) | det ( d d z h -1 ( z ) ) |
Solution.  It is z=h( y ) ↔ y= h -1 ( z )
For if  h nnearrow it is F z ( z ) = P ( Z ≤ z ) = P ( h -1 ( Z ) ≤ h -1 ( z ) ) = P ( Y ≤ h -1 ( z ) ) = F Y ( h -1 ( z ) ) and f z ( z ) = d d z F z ( z ) = d d z F Y ( h -1 ( z ) ) = d d h -1 F Y ( h -1 ) det ( d d z h -1 ( z ) ) For if  h ssearrow it is F z ( z ) = P ( Z ≤ z ) = P ( h -1 ( Z ) ≥ h -1 ( z ) ) = P ( Y ≥ h -1 ( z ) ) =1- F Y ( h -1 ( z ) ) and f z ( z ) = d d z F z ( z ) = d d z [ 1- F Y ( h -1 ( z ) ) ] =- d d h -1 F Y ( h -1 ) det ( d d z h -1 ( z ) ) but det ( d d z h -1 ( z ) ) <0 because h ssearrow . So in both cases: f z ( z ) = f y ( h -1 ( z ) ) | det ( d d z h -1 ( z ) ) |

Exercise 7. ( ★ )
Let y ∼ Ex ( λ ) r.v. with Exponential distribution with rate parameter λ >0 , and f Ex ( λ ) ( y ) = λ exp ( - λ y ) 1 ( y ≥ 0 ) . Let z=1- exp ( - λ y ) . Calculate the PDF of z , and recognize its distribution.
Solution. It is z=1- exp ( - λ y ) ⟺ y=- 1 λ log ( 1-z ) , and z ∈ [ 0,1 ] . So h -1 ( z ) =- 1 λ log ( 1-z ) . Then f z ( z ) = f Ex ( λ ) ( h -1 ( z ) ) × | det ( d d z h -1 ( z ) ) | = f Ex ( λ ) ( - 1 λ log ( 1-z ) ) × | det ( d d z -1 λ log ( 1-z ) ) | = exp ( - λ -1 λ log ( 1-z ) ) 1 ( - 1 λ log ( 1-z ) ≥ 0 ) × | - 1 λ 1 1-z | = 1 ( z ∈ [ 0,1 ] ) From the density, we recognize that z ∼ U ( 0,1 ) follows a uniform distribution.
Exercise 8. ( ★ )
Prove the following properties
  1. Let matrix A ∈ R q × d , c ∈ R q , and z=c+Ay then E ( z ) = E ( c+Ay ) =c+A E ( y )
  2. Let random variables z ∈ Z and y ∈ Y , and let functions ψ 1 and ψ 2 defined on Z and Y , then E ( ψ 1 ( z ) + ψ 2 ( y ) ) = E ( ψ 1 ( z ) ) + E ( ψ 2 ( y ) )
  3. If random variables z ∈ Z and y ∈ Y are independent then E ( ψ 1 ( z ) ψ 2 ( y ) ) = E ( ψ 1 ( z ) ) E ( ψ 2 ( y ) ) for any functions ψ 1 and ψ 2 defined on Z and Y .
Solution.  
  1. It is E ( z ) = E ( c+Ay ) = ∫ ( c+Ay ) d F( y ) =c+A ∫ y d F( y ) =c+A E ( y )
  2. It is E ( ψ 1 ( z ) + ψ 2 ( y ) ) = ∫ ( ψ 1 ( z ) + ψ 2 ( y ) ) d F( ( z,y ) ) = ∫ ψ 1 ( z ) d F( ( z,y ) ) + ∫ ψ 1 ( z ) d F( ( z,y ) ) = ∫ ψ 1 ( z ) d F( z ) + ∫ ψ 1 ( z ) d F( z ) = E ( ψ 1 ( z ) ) + E ( ψ 2 ( y ) )
  3. If random variables z ∈ Z and y ∈ Y then d F( z,y ) = d F( z ) d F( y ) It is E ( ψ 1 ( z ) ψ 2 ( y ) ) = ∫ ( ψ 1 ( z ) ψ 2 ( y ) ) d F( ( z,y ) ) =( ∫ ψ 1 ( z ) d F( z ) ) ( ∫ ψ 2 ( y ) d F( y ) )

Exercise 9. ( ★ )
Prove the following properties of the covariance matrix
  1. Cov ( z,y ) = E ( z y ⊤ ) - E ( z ) ( E ( y ) ) ⊤
  2. Cov ( z,y ) = ( Cov ( y,z ) ) ⊤
  3. Cov π ( c 1 + A 1 z, c 2 + A 2 y ) = A 1 Cov π ( x,y ) A 2 ⊤ , for fixed matrices A 1 , A 2 , and vectors c 1 , c 2 with suitable dimensions.
  4. If z and y are independent random vectors then Cov ( z,y ) =0

Solution.  
  1. It is Cov ( z,y ) = E ( ( z- E ( z ) ) (y- E ( y ) ) ⊤ ) E ( z y ⊤ -z E (y ) ⊤ - E ( z ) y ⊤ + E ( z ) E (y ) ⊤ ) = E ( z y ⊤ ) - E ( z ) ( E ( y ) ) ⊤
  2. It is ( Cov ( y,z ) ) ⊤ = ( E ( ( z- E ( z ) ) (y- E ( y ) ) ⊤ ) ) ⊤ = E ( ( ( z- E ( z ) ) (y- E ( y ) ) ⊤ ) ) ⊤ = E ( ( y- E ( y ) ) (z- E ( z ) ) ⊤ ) = Cov ( y,z )
  3. It is Cov ( c 1 + A 1 z, c 2 + A 2 y ) = E ( ( c 1 + A 1 z ) ( c 2 + A 2 y ) ⊤ ) - E ( c 1 + A 1 z ) ( E ( c 2 + A 2 y ) ) ⊤ =...= A 1 ( E ( z y ⊤ ) - E ( z ) ( E ( y ) ) ⊤ ) A 2 ⊤ = A 1 Cov ( z,y ) A 2 ⊤
  4. Obviously since Cov ( z,y ) =0 ⟺ Cov ( z i , y j ) ={ i=j i ≠ j

Exercise 10. ( ★ )
Prove that the ( i,j ) -th element of the covariance matrix between vector z and y is the covariance between their elements z i and y j : [ Cov ( z,y ) ] i,j = Cov ( z i , y j )
Solution.  
It is [ Cov ( z,y ) ] i,j = [ E ( z y ⊤ ) - E ( z ) ( E ( y ) ) ⊤ ] i,j = = [ E ( z y ⊤ ) ] i,j - [ E ( z ) ( E ( y ) ) ⊤ ] i,j = E ( z i y j ⊤ ) - E ( z i ) ( E ( y j ) ) ⊤ = Cov ( z i , y j )

Exercise 11. ( ★ )
Prove the following properties of Var ( Y ) for a random vector y ∈ Y ⊆ R d
  1. Var ( y ) = E ( y y ⊤ ) - E ( y ) ( E ( y ) ) ⊤
  2. Var ( c+Ay ) =A Var ( y ) A ⊤ , for fixed matrix A , and vectors c with suitable dimensions.
  3. Var ( y ) ≥ 0 ; (semi-positive definite)
Solution.  
  1. Var ( y ) = Cov ( y,y ) = E ( y y ⊤ ) - E ( y ) ( E ( y ) ) ⊤
  2. Var ( c+Ay ) = Cov ( c+Ay,c+Ay ) =A Cov ( y,y ) A ⊤ =A Var ( y ) A ⊤
  3. For any vector x ∈ R q t ⊤ Var ( y ) t = t ⊤ E ( ( y- E ( y ) ) (y- E ( y ) ) ⊤ ) t = E ( ( t ⊤ ( y- E ( y ) ) ) ( t ⊤ ( y- E ( y ) ) ) ⊤ ) = E ( z z ⊤ ) = E ( ∑ j=1 d z j 2 ) ≥ 0 for z= t ⊤ ( y- E ( y ) ) .

Exercise 12. ( ★ )
Prove the following properties of characteristic functions
  1. ϕ A+Bx ( t ) = e i t T A ϕ x ( B T t ) if A ∈ R d and B ∈ R k × d are constants
  2. ϕ x+y ( t ) = ϕ x ( t ) ϕ y ( t ) if and only if x and y are independent
  3. if M x ( t ) = E ( e t T x ) is the moment generating function, then M x ( t ) = ϕ x ( -it )
Solution.  
  1. It is ϕ A+Bx ( t ) = E ( e i t T ( A+Bx ) ) = E ( e A+i t T Bx ) = E ( e i t T A e i B T tx ) = e i t T A E ( e i( B T t ) x ) = e i t T A ϕ x ( B T t )
  2. straightforward
  3. straightforward
Exercise 13. ( ★ )
Show that if X ∼ Ex ( λ ) then ϕ X ( t ) = λ λ -it .

Solution.  It is ϕ X ( t ) = ∫ - ∞ ∞ e itX λ e - λ x 1 ( X>0 ) ⏟ = f Ex ( x| λ ) d x= λ ∫ - ∞ ∞ e -x( λ -itX ) d x= λ λ -it

Exercise 14. ( ★ )
 
  1. Find ϕ X ( t ) if X ∼ Br ( p ) .
  2. Find ϕ Y ( t ) if Y ∼ Bin ( n,p )
Solution.  
  1. It is ϕ X ( t ) = ∑ x=0,1 e itX P( X=x ) = e it0 ( 1-p ) + e it1 p=( 1-p ) +p e it
  2. Because Binomial r.v. results as a summation of n IID Bernoulli r.v., it is Y= ∑ i=1 n X i , where X i ∼ Br ( p ) i=1,...,n and IID. Then ϕ Y ( t ) = ϕ ∑ X i ( t ) = ∏ i=1 n ϕ X i ( t ) =(( 1-p ) +p e it ) n

Prove the following statement related to the Bayesian theorem:

Then the probability density function (PDF), or the probability mass function (PMF) of θ |x is f( θ |x ) = f( x| θ ) f( θ ) ∫ f( x| θ ) d F( θ ) (1)

By Bayes theorem it is P( θ ∈ Θ 0 |x ) = P( Θ 0 ,x ) P( x ) where P( x ) = ∫ Θ f( x| θ ) d F( θ ) and P( Θ 0 ,x ) = ∫ Θ 0 f( x| θ ) d F( θ ) .

By Bayes theorem P( θ ∈ Θ 0 | B r ( x ) ) = P( Θ 0 , B r ( x ) ) P( B r ( x ) ) where P( Θ 0 , B r ( x ) ) = ∫ Θ 0 [ ∫ B r ( x ) f( ζ | θ ) d ζ ] d F( θ ) P( B r ( x ) ) = ∫ Θ [ ∫ B r ( x ) f( ζ | θ ) d ζ ] d F( θ ) By mean value theorem

Exercise 16. ( ★ )
Prove that:
  1. if Z ∼ N ( 0,I ) then ϕ Z ( t ) = exp ( - 1 2 t T t ) , where Z ∈ R d
  2. if X ∼ N ( μ , Σ ) then ϕ X ( t ) = exp ( i t T μ - 1 2 t T Σ t ) , where X ∈ R d
Hint:
Assume as known that if Z ∼ N ( 0,1 ) then ϕ Z ( t ) = exp ( - 1 2 t 2 ) , where Z ∈ R
Solution.  
  1. It is ϕ Z ( t ) = E ( exp ( i t T Z ) ) = E ( exp ( i ∑ j=1 d ( t j Z j ) ) ) = E ( ∏ j=1 d exp ( i t j Z j ) ) = ∏ j=1 d E ( exp ( i t j Z j ) ) = ∏ j=1 d ϕ Z j ( t ) = ∏ j=1 d exp ( - 1 2 t j 2 ) = exp ( - 1 2 ∑ j=1 d t j 2 ) = exp ( - 1 2 t T t )
  2. Assume a matrix L such as Σ =L L T . It is X= μ +LZ . Then ϕ X ( t ) = ϕ μ +LZ ( t ) = e i t T μ ϕ Z ( L T t ) = e i t T μ exp (- 1 2 ( L T t ) T L T t ) = e i t T μ exp ( - 1 2 t T L L T t ) = exp ( i t T μ - 1 2 t T Σ t )
Exercise 17. ( ★ )
Show the following properties of the Characteristic Function
  1. ϕ x ( 0 ) =1 and | ϕ x ( t ) | ≤ 1 for all t ∈ R d
  2. ϕ A+Bx ( t ) = e i t T A ϕ x ( B T t ) if A ∈ R d and B ∈ R k × d are constants
  3. x and y are independent then ϕ x+y ( t ) = ϕ x ( t ) ϕ y ( t ) (we do not proov the other way around)
  4. if M x ( t ) = E ( e t T x ) is the moment generating function, then M x ( t ) = ϕ x ( -it )
Solution.  
  1. It is ϕ x ( 0 ) = E ( e i 0 T x ) = E ( 1 ) =1 . Also | ϕ x ( t ) | =| E ( e i t T x ) | =| ∫ ( cos ( t T x ) +i sin ( t T x ) ) d F( x ) | ≤ ∫ | cos ( t T x ) +i sin ( t T x ) | d F( x ) ≤ ∫ 1 d F( x ) =1
  2. It is ϕ A+Bx ( t ) = E ( e i t T ( A+Bx ) ) = E ( e i t T A+Bi t T x ) = E ( e Ai e i( B T t ) ⊤ x ) = e i t T A ϕ x ( B T t )
  3. It is ϕ x+y ( t ) = E ( e i t T ( x+y ) ) = E ( e i t T x e i t T y ) = E ( e i t T x ) E ( e i t T y ) = ϕ x ( t ) ϕ y ( t )

Part III Probability calculus

Exercise 18. ( ★ )
Let a random variable x ∼ IG ( a,b ) , a fixed value c>0 , and y=cx then y ∼ IG ( a,cb ) .

Solution.   It is y=cx and x= 1 c y f( y ) = f IG ( a,b ) ( x ) | d x d y | ∝ ( 1 c y ) -a-1 exp ( - b 1 c y ) 1 ( 0,+ ∞ ) ( 1 c y ) 1 c ∝ y -a-1 exp ( - cb y ) 1 ( 0,+ ∞ ) ( y ) = f IG ( a,cb ) ( y )

Exercise 19. ( ★ ★ ★ )
Consider that x given z is distributed according to Ga ( n 2 , nz 2 ) , and that z is distributed according to Ga ( m 2 , m 2 ); i.e. { x|z ∼ Ga ( n 2 , nz 2 ) z ∼ Ga ( m 2 , m 2 ) Here, Ga ( α , β ) is the Gamma distribution with shape and rate parameters α and β , and PDF f Ga ( α , β ) ( x ) = β α Γ ( α ) x α -1 e - β x 1 ( x>0 )
  1. Show that the compound distribution of x is F x ∼ F ( n,m ) , where F ( n,m ) is F distribution with numerator and denumerator degrees of freedom n and m , and PDF f F ( n,m ) ( x ) = 1 x B ( n 2 , m 2 ) (nx ) n m m (nx+m ) n+m 1 ( x>0 )
  2. Show that E F ( n,m ) ( x ) = m m-2
  3. Show that Var F ( n,m ) ( x ) = 2 m 2 ( n+m-2 ) n(m-2 ) 2 ( m-4 )
Hint:
If ξ ∼ IG ( a,b ) then E ξ ∼ IG ( a,b ) ( ξ ) = b a-1 , and Var ξ ∼ IG ( a,b ) ( ξ ) = b 2 (a-1 ) 2 ( a-2 )
Solution.  
  1. It is f Ga ( n 2 , nz 2 ) ( x|z ) = ( nz 2 ) n 2 Γ ( n 2 ) x n 2 -1 e - nz 2 x 1 ( x>0 ) ; f Ga ( m 2 , m 2 ) ( z ) = ( m 2 ) m 2 Γ ( m 2 ) z m 2 -1 e - m 2 z 1 ( z>0 ) So: f( x ) = ∫ f Ga ( n 2 , nz 2 ) ( x|z ) f Ga ( m 2 , m 2 ) ( z ) d z = ∫ ( nz 2 ) n 2 Γ ( n 2 ) x n 2 -1 e - nz 2 x 1 ( x>0 ) ⏞ = f Ga ( n 2 , nz 2 ) ( x|z ) ( m 2 ) m 2 Γ ( m 2 ) z m 2 -1 e - m 2 z 1 ( z>0 ) ⏞ = f Ga ( m 2 , m 2 ) ( z ) d z = ( n 2 ) n 2 Γ ( n 2 ) ( m 2 ) m 2 Γ ( m 2 ) 1 ( x>0 ) x n 2 -1 ∫ 0 ∞ z n 2 e - nx 2 z z m 2 -1 e - m 2 z d z = ( n 2 ) n 2 Γ ( n 2 ) ( m 2 ) m 2 Γ ( m 2 ) 1 ( x>0 ) x n 2 -1 ∫ 0 ∞ z n 2 + m 2 -1 e -( m 2 + nx 2 ) z d z = ( n 2 ) n 2 ( m 2 ) m 2 B ( n 2 , m 2 ) 1 ( x>0 ) x n 2 -1 ( m 2 + nx 2 ) -( n 2 + m 2 ) = (n ) n 2 (m ) m 2 B ( n 2 , m 2 ) 1 x x n ( m+nx ) n+m 1 ( x>0 ) = 1 x B ( n 2 , m 2 ) (nx ) n m m (nx+m ) n+m 1 ( x>0 )
  2. It is E ( x ) = E Ga ( m 2 , m 2 ) ( E Ga ( n 2 , nz 2 ) ( x|z ) ) = E z ∼ Ga ( m 2 , m 2 ) ( 1 z ) = E ξ ∼ IG ( m 2 , m 2 ) ( ξ ) = m 2 m 2 -1 = m m-2
  3. It is Var ( x ) = E Ga ( m 2 , m 2 ) ( Var Ga ( n 2 , nz 2 ) ( x|z ) ) + Var Ga ( m 2 , m 2 ) ( E Ga ( n 2 , nz 2 ) ( x|z ) ) = E Ga ( m 2 , m 2 ) ( 2 n z 2 ) + Var Ga ( m 2 , m 2 ) ( 1 z ) = 2 n E Ga ( m 2 , m 2 ) ( 1 z 2 ) + Var Ga ( m 2 , m 2 ) ( 1 z ) = 2 n E ξ ∼ IG ( m 2 , m 2 ) ( ξ 2 ) + Var ξ ∼ IG ( m 2 , m 2 ) ( ξ ) = 2 n ( ( m 2 ) 2 ( m 2 -1 ) ( m 2 -2 ) ) +( m 2 m 2 -1 ) = ...= 2 m 2 ( n+m-2 ) n(m-2 ) 2 ( m-4 )
Exercise 20. ( ★ ★ )
Prove the following statement:
Let x ∼ N d ( μ , Σ ) , x ∈ R d , and y=(x- μ ) ⊤ Σ -1 ( x- μ ) . Then y ∼ χ d 2
Solution. It is y=(x- μ ) ⊤ Σ -1 ( x- μ ) = ( Σ -1/2 ( x- μ ) ) ⊤ ( Σ -1/2 ( x- μ ) ) = z ⊤ z= ∑ i=1 d z i 2 where z= Σ -1/2 ( x- μ ) , and z ∼ N d ( 0,I ) . Because z i ∼ N ( 0,1 ) , it is ∑ i=1 d z i 2 ∼ χ d 2 (from stats concepts 2).
Exercise 21. ( ★ ★ )
Let { x| ξ ∼ N d ( μ , Σ ξ ) ξ ∼ IG ( a,b ) with PDF f N d ( μ , Σ ξ ) ( x| ξ ) =(2 π ) - d 2 det ( Σ ) - 1 2 exp ( - 1 2 (x- μ ) ⊤ Σ -1 ( x- μ ) ) f IG ( a,b ) ( ξ ) = b a Γ ( a ) ξ -a-1 exp ( - b ξ ) 1 ( 0, ∞ ) ( ξ ) Show that the marginal PDF of x is f( x ) = ∫ f N d ( μ , Σ ξ ) ( x| ξ ) f IG ( a,b ) ( ξ ) d ξ = 2 a - d 2 π n 2 det ( b a Σ ) Γ ( a+ d 2 ) Γ ( a ) [ 1+ 1 2a (x- μ ) ⊤ ( b a Σ ) -1 ( x- μ ) ] - ( 2a+d ) 2 (2)
FYI:
For a=b= v 2 , the marginal PDF is the PDF of the d -dimensional Student T distribution.

Exercise 22. ( ★ ★ ★ )
Let x ∼ T d ( μ , Σ , ν ) . Recall that x ∼ T d ( μ , Σ , ν ) is the marginal distribution f x ( x ) = ∫ f x| ξ ( x| ξ ) f ξ ( ξ ) d ξ of ( x, ξ ) where x| ξ ∼ N d ( μ , Σ ξ v ) ξ ∼ IG ( v 2 , 1 2 ) Consider partition such that x= [ x 1 x 2 ]; μ = [ μ 1 μ 2 ]; Σ = [ Σ 1 Σ 21 ⊤ Σ 21 Σ 2 ], where x 1 ∈ R d 1 and x 2 ∈ R d 2 .
Address the following:
  1. Show that the marginal distribution of x 1 is such that x 1 ∼ T d 1 ( μ 1 , Σ 1 , ν )
    Hint:
    Try to use the form f x ( x ) = ∫ f x| ξ ( x| ξ ) f ξ ( ξ ) d ξ .
  2. Show that ξ | x 1 ∼ IG ( 1 2 ( d 1 +v ) , 1 2 Q+v v ) where Q=( μ 1 - x 1 ) ⊤ Σ 1 -1 ( μ 1 - x 1 ) .
    Hint:
    The PDF of y ∼ N d ( μ , Σ ) is f( y ) =(2 π ) - d 2 det ( Σ ) - 1 2 exp ( - 1 2 (y- μ ) ⊤ Σ -1 ( y- μ ) )
    Hint:
    The PDF of y ∼ IG ( a,b ) is f IG ( a,b ) ( y ) = b a Γ ( a ) y -a-1 exp ( - b y ) 1 ( 0,+ ∞ ) ( y )
  3. Let ξ '= ξ v Q+v , with Q=( μ 1 - x 1 ) ⊤ Σ 1 -1 ( μ 1 - x 1 ) , show that ξ '| x 1 ∼ IG ( v+ d 1 2 , 1 2 )
  4. Show that the conditional distribution of x 2 | x 1 is such that x 2 | x 1 ∼ T d 2 ( μ 2|1 , Σ ˙ 2|1 , ν 2|1 ) where μ 2|1 = μ 2 + Σ 21 Σ 11 -1 ( x 1 - μ 1 ) Σ ˙ 2|1 = ν +( μ 1 - x 1 ) ⊤ Σ 1 -1 ( μ 1 - x 1 ) ν + d 1 Σ 2|1 Σ 2|1 = Σ 22 - Σ 21 Σ 1 -1 Σ 21 ⊤ ν 2|1 = ν + d 1
    Hint:
    You can use the Example [Marginalization & conditioning] from the Lecture Handout

Solution.    
  1. From what is given, it is x| ξ ∼ N d ( μ , Σ ξ v ) and ξ ∼ IG ( v 2 , 1 2 ) namely, f x ( x ) = ∫ f x 1 , x 2 | ξ ( x 1 , x 2 | ξ ) f ξ ( ξ ) d ξ = ∫ f x 2 | ξ , x 1 ( x 2 | ξ , x 1 ) f x 1 | ξ ( x 1 | ξ ) f ξ ( ξ ) d ξ It is f x 1 ( x 1 ) = ∫ ∫ f x 1 , x 2 | ξ ( x 1 , x 2 | ξ ) f ξ ( ξ ) d ξ d x 2 = ∫ ∫ f x 2 | ξ , x 1 ( x 2 | ξ , x 1 ) f x 1 | ξ ( x 1 | ξ ) f ξ ( ξ ) d ξ d x 2 = ∫ ( ∫ f x 2 | ξ , x 1 ( x 2 | ξ , x 1 ) d x 2 ) f x 1 | ξ ( x 1 | ξ ) f ξ ( ξ ) d ξ = ∫ f x 1 | ξ ( x 1 | ξ ) f ξ ( ξ ) d ξ
    Because x 1 | ξ ∼ N d 1 ( μ 1 , Σ 1 ξ v ) , and ξ ∼ IG ( v 2 , 1 2 ) , it is x 1 ∼ T d 1 ( μ 1 , Σ 1 , ν ) from the statement of the question.
  2. From what is given, it is x| ξ ∼ N d ( μ , Σ ξ v ) , and hence x 1 | ξ ∼ N d ( μ 1 , Σ 1 ξ v ) as marginal of a Normal distribution. From the Bayes Theorem, it is f ξ | x 1 ( ξ | x 1 ) ∝ f x 1 | ξ ( x 1 | ξ ) f( ξ ) ∝ ξ - d 1 2 exp ( - 1 2 ( x 1 - μ 1 ) ⊤ ( Σ 1 ξ v ) -1 ( x 1 - μ 1 ) ) × ξ - d 1 +v 2 -1 exp ( - 1 ξ 1 2 ) ∝ ξ - d 1 +v 2 -1 exp ( - 1 ξ 1 2 [ ( x 1 - μ 1 ) ⊤ Σ 1 -1 ( x 1 - μ 1 ) 1 v +1 ] ) ∝ ξ - d 1 +v 2 -1 exp ( - 1 ξ 1 2 Q+v v ) This is the kernel of the Inverse Gamma distribution, and hence I can recognize that ξ | x 1 ∼ IG ( 1 2 ( d 1 +v ) , 1 2 Q+v v ) .
  3. Let ξ '= ξ v Q+v , with Q=( μ 1 - x 1 ) ⊤ Σ 1 -1 ( μ 1 - x 1 ) . Then it is f( ξ '| x 1 ) = f IG ( 1 2 ( d 1 +v ) , 1 2 Q+v v ) ( ξ | x 1 ) | d ξ d ξ ' | ∝ (Q ξ ' ) - d 1 +v 2 -1 exp ( - 1 2 Q+v v 1 Q+v v ξ ' ) 1 ( 0,+ ∞ ) ( Q+v v ξ ' ) Q+v v ∝ ( ξ ' ) - d 1 +v 2 -1 exp ( - 1 2 1 ξ ' ) 1 ( 0,+ ∞ ) ( ξ ' ) = f IG ( v+ d 1 2 , 1 2 ) ( ξ ' ) So ξ '| x 1 ∼ IG ( v+ d 1 2 , 1 2 )
  4. I will try to show that x 2 | ξ ', x 1 ∼ N d 2 ( μ 2|1 ,( v+ d 1 ) Σ ˙ 2|1 ξ ' ) ξ '| x 1 ∼ IG ( v+ d 1 2 , 1 2 ) which leads to x 2 | x 1 ∼ T d 2 ( μ 2|1 , Σ ˙ 2|1 , ν 2|1 ) since because f x 2 | x 1 ( x 2 | x 1 ) = ∫ f x 2 | ξ , x 1 ( x 2 | ξ , x 1 ) f ξ ( ξ | x 1 ) d ξ
    • I have calculated that ξ '| x 1 ∼ IG ( v+ d 1 2 , 1 2 ) where ξ '= ξ v Q+v with Q=( μ 1 - x 1 ) ⊤ Σ 1 -1 ( μ 1 - x 1 ) .
    • It is (from multivariate Normal properties of the Example in the Hint) x 2 | ξ , x 1 ∼ N d 2 ( μ 2|1 ,( Σ 22 - Σ 21 Σ 1 -1 Σ 21 ⊤ ⏟ = Σ 2|1 ) ξ v ) ≡ N d 2 ( μ 2|1 , Σ 2|1 v ξ ) where μ 2|1 = μ 2 + Σ 21 Σ 11 -1 ( x 1 - μ 1 ) . If I rearrange the parameters in order to appear ξ '= ξ v Q+v in the covariance I get x 2 | ξ , x 1 ∼ N d 2 ( μ 2|1 , Σ 2|1 v ξ ' v+Q v v+ d 1 v+ d 1 ) By setting Σ ˙ 2|1 = Σ 2|1 v+Q v+ d 1 I get x 2 | ξ ', x 1 ∼ N d 2 ( μ 2|1 ,( v+ d 1 ) Σ ˙ 2|1 ξ ' )
    So I have x 2 | ξ ', x 1 ∼ N d 2 ( μ 2|1 ,( v+ d 1 ) Σ ˙ 2|1 ξ ' ) ξ '| x 1 ∼ IG ( v+ d 1 2 , 1 2 )
    which gives that x 2 | x 1 ∼ T d 2 ( μ 2|1 , Σ ˙ 2|1 , ν 2|1 ) with ν 2|1 =v+ d 1 . So the distribution of x 2 | x 1 is x 2 | x 1 ∼ T d 2 ( μ 2|1 , Σ ˙ 2|1 , ν 2|1 ) .
Note:
Alternatively, one could prove sub-questions (2) and (4) by performing several pages of Matrix calculations to show that f X ( x| μ , Σ ) = Γ ( ν +d 2 ) Γ ( ν 2 ) ν d 2 π d 2 det ( Σ ) 1 2 ( 1+ 1 v (x- μ ) T Σ -1 ( x- μ ) ) - ν +d 2 = ... = Γ ( ν + d 1 2 ) Γ ( ν 2 ) ν d 1 2 π d 1 2 det ( Σ 1 ) 1 2 ( 1+ 1 v ( x 1 - μ 1 ) T Σ 1 -1 ( x 1 - μ 1 ) ) - ν + d 1 2 × Γ ( ν 2|1 + d 2 2 ) Γ ( ν 2|1 2 ) ν 2|1 d 2 2 π d 2 2 det ( Σ ˙ 2|1 ) 1 2 ( 1+ 1 v 2|1 ( x 2 - μ 2|1 ) T Σ ˙ 2|1 -1 ( x 2 - μ 2|1 ) ) - ν 2|1 + d 2 2 see Raiffa, H., & Schlaifer, R. (1961; Section 8.3). Applied statistical decision theory. This requires a lot of vector and matrix calculus.

Exercise 23. ( ★ ★ ★ )
Show that
  1. If x i ∼ N d ( μ i , Σ i ) for i=1,..,n and y=c+ ∑ i=1 n B i x i , then y ∼ N d ( c+ ∑ i=1 n μ i , ∑ i=1 n B i Σ i B i ⊤ )
  2. If x i ∼ T d ( μ i , Σ i ,v ) for i=1,..,n and z=c+ ∑ i=1 n B i x i , then z ∼ T d ( c+ ∑ i=1 n μ i , ∑ i=1 n B i Σ i B i ⊤ ,v )
Solution.  
  1. For any a ∈ R d a ⊤ y= a ⊤ ( c+ ∑ i=1 n B i x i ) = a ⊤ c+ ∑ i=1 n a ⊤ B i x i = a ⊤ c+ ∑ i=1 n ( B i ⊤ a ) ⊤ x i follows a univariate Normal distribution. So y follows a d -dimensional Normal by definition. Also E ( y ) = E ( c+ ∑ i=1 n B i x i ) =c+ ∑ i=1 n μ i and Var ( y ) = Var ( c+ ∑ i=1 n B i x i ) = ∑ i=1 n B i Var ( x i ) B i ⊤ = ∑ i=1 n B i Σ i B i ⊤ So by definition y ∼ N d ( c+ ∑ i=1 n μ i , ∑ i=1 n B i Σ i B i ⊤ ) .
  2. It is z=c+ ∑ i=1 n B i x i =c+ ∑ i=1 n B i ( μ i + y i v ξ ) =( c+ ∑ i=1 n B i μ i ) +( ∑ i=1 n B i y i ) v ξ for y i ∼ N d ( 0, Σ i ) and ξ ∼ IG ( v 2 , 1 2 ) , and hence z=( c+ ∑ i=1 n B i μ i ) + y ˜ v ξ where y ˜ ∼ N d ( 0, ∑ i=1 n B i Σ i B i ⊤ ) . Hence, z ∼ T d ( c+ ∑ i=1 n μ i , ∑ i=1 n B i Σ i B i ⊤ ,v ) by definition.

Exercise 24. ( ★ )
Consider an i.i.d. sample y 1 , …, y n from the skew-logistic distribution with PDF f( y i | θ ) = θ e - y i (1+ e - y i ) θ +1 with parameter θ ∈ ( 0, ∞ ) . To account for the uncertainty about θ we assign a Gamma prior distribution with PDF π ( θ ) = b a Γ ( a ) θ a-1 e -b θ 1 ( θ ∈ ( 0, ∞ ) ) , and fixed hyper parameters a,b specified by the researcher's prior info.
  1. Derive the posterior distribution of θ .
  2. Derive the predictive PDF for a future z= y n+1 .
Solution.   It is f( y i | θ ) = θ e - y i (1+ e - y i ) θ +1 = θ e - y i ( 1+ e - y i ) exp ( - θ log ( 1+ e - y i ) )
  1. By using the Bayes theorem π ( θ |y ) ∝ f( y| θ ) π ( θ ) ∝ ∏ i=1 n f( y i | θ ) π ( θ ) = ∏ i=1 n θ e - y i (1+ e - y i ) θ +1 b a Γ ( a ) θ a-1 e -b θ 1 ( θ ∈ ( 0, ∞ ) ) ∝ ∏ i=1 n e - y i ( 1+ e - y i ) θ n ∏ i=1 n exp ( - θ log ( 1+ e - y i ) ) b a Γ ( a ) θ a-1 e -b θ 1 ( θ ∈ ( 0, ∞ ) ) ∝ θ n+a-1 exp ( - θ [ ∑ i=1 n log ( 1+ e - y i ) +b ] ) 1 ( θ ∈ ( 0, ∞ ) ) ∝ Ga ( θ |a+n,b+ ∑ i=1 n log ( 1+ e - y i ) ) So θ |y ∼ Ga ( a+n ⏟ = a * , b+ ∑ i=1 n log ( 1+ e - y i ) ⏟ = b * )
  2. By using the definition for the predictive PDF, it is f( z|y ) = ∫ R f( z| θ ) π ( θ |y ) d θ = ∫ R + e -z ( 1+ e -z ) θ exp ( - θ log ( 1+ e -z ) ) ( b * ) a * Γ ( a * ) θ a * -1 exp ( - θ b * ) d θ = ( b * ) a * Γ ( a * ) e -z ( 1+ e -z ) ∫ R + θ a * +1-1 exp ( - θ ( b * + log ( 1+ e -y ) ) ) d θ = ( b * ) a * Γ ( a * ) e -z ( 1+ e -z ) Γ ( a * +1 ) ( b * + log ( 1+ e -z ) ) a * +1 = e -z ( 1+ e -z ) ( b * ) a * ( b * + log ( 1+ e -z ) ) a * +1 a *
The following exercise is about Bayesian treatment in problems with nuisance unknown parameters
  • Assume observable quantities y=( y 1 ,..., y n ) . Assume that the sampling distribution is F( y| θ ) labeled by an unknown parameter θ ∈ Θ . Let θ =( φ , λ ) ⊤ with φ ∈ Φ and λ ∈ Λ . Assume You are interested in learning parameter φ ∈ Φ , and You are not interested in learning the unknown parameter λ ∈ Λ ; but both φ , λ are parts of the statistical model parameterisation. The unknown quantity λ ∈ Λ is called nuisance parameter. We an call φ ∈ Φ parameter of interest.
  • In Bayesian Stats, learning (or quantifying uncertainty about) parameter of interest φ under the presence of a nuisance parameter λ ∈ Λ is performed according to the Bayesian paradigm as usual: You specify a prior Π ( φ , λ ) with PDF/PMF π ( φ , λ ) = π ( φ | λ ) π ( λ ) on the joint space of ALL Your unknown parameters θ =( φ , λ ) ⊤ ; you compute the joint posterior distribution d Π ( θ |y ) of θ =( φ , λ ) ⊤ via the Bayesian theorem. Reasonably, Your posterior degree of believe about the parameter of interest φ given the data y=( 1 1 ,..., y n ) is given through the marginal posterior distribution d Π ( φ |y ) .
  • To summarize; Specify the Bayesian model as: { y| φ , λ ⏞ = θ ∼ d F( y| φ , λ ⏞ = θ ) , the statistical model ( φ , λ ⏟ = θ ) ∼ d Π ( φ , λ ⏟ = θ ) , the prior model The joint posterior of θ given y is d Π ( θ |y ) = d Π ( λ |y, φ ) d Π ( φ |y ) is with PDF/PMF
  • π ( φ , λ ⏞ = θ |y ) = f( y| φ , λ ⏞ = θ ) π ( φ , λ ⏞ = θ ) f( y ) = f( y| φ , λ ) π ( λ | φ ) f( y| φ ) ⏟ = π ( λ |y, φ ) f( y| φ ) π ( φ ) f( y ) ⏟ = π ( φ |y ) = π ( λ |y, φ ) π ( φ |y ) The (marginal) likelihood f( y| φ ) of y given φ is f( y| φ ) = ∫ Λ f( y| φ , λ ⏞ = θ ) d Π ( λ | φ ) ⏟ = E Π ( λ | φ ) ( f( y| φ , λ ) | φ ) ={ ∫ Λ f( y| φ , λ ) π ( λ | φ ) d λ , if λ cont ∑ ∀ λ ∈ Λ f( y| φ , λ ) π ( λ | φ ) , if λ discr The PDF/PMF π ( φ |y ) of marginal posterior d Π ( φ |y ) of φ is π ( φ |y ) = ∫ Λ π ( φ , λ ⏞ = θ |y ) d λ ⏟ = E Π ( λ |y ) ( π ( φ |y, λ ) ) or equivalently  π ( φ |y ) = f( y| φ ) π ( φ ) f( y ) The predictive distribution G( z|y ) of the next outcome z=( y n+1 ,... y n+m ) given y has pdf/pmf g( z|y ) = ∫ f( y| φ , λ ⏞ = θ ) d Π ( φ , λ ⏞ = θ |y ) and the marginal likelihood f( y ) is f( y ) = ∫ f( y| φ , λ ⏞ = θ ) π ( φ , λ ⏞ = θ ) d φ d λ

The following is about the Normal linear model of regression.
Exercise 26. ( ★ ★ ★ )
(Normal linear regression model with unknown error variance)
<-story
Consider we are interested in recovering the mapping
in the sense that y is the response (output quantity) that depends on x which is the independent variable (input quantity) in a procedure; E.g.:,
  • y : precipitation in log scale
  • x=( longitude , latitude ) : geographical coordinates.
It is believed that the mapping η ( x ) can be represented as an expansion of d known polynomial functions { φ j ( x ) } j=0 d-1 such as η ( x ) = ∑ j=0 d-1 φ j ( x ) β j = Φ (x ) ⊤ β ; with  Φ ( x ) =( φ 0 ( x ) ,..., φ d-1 ( x ) ) ⊤ where β ∈ R d is unknown.
Assume observable quantities (data) in pairs ( x i , y i ) for i=1,...,n ; (E.g. from the i -th station at location x i I got the reading y i ). Assume that the response observations y=( y 1 ,..., y n ) may be contaminated by noise with unknown variance; such that y i = η ( x i ) + ε i where ε i ∼ N ( 0, σ 2 ) with unknown σ 2 .
You are interested in learning β , but you do not care about σ 2 . Also you want to learn the value of y f at an untried x f (i.e. the precipitation at any other location).
Consider the Bayesian model
<-set-up
y| β , σ 2 ∼ N ( Φ β ,I σ 2 ) ; the sampling distr β | σ 2 ∼ N ( μ 0 , V 0 σ 2 ) ; prior distr σ 2 ∼ IG ( a 0 , k 0 ) prior  distr where Φ is the design matrix [ Φ ] i,j = Φ j ( x i ) .
  1. Show that the joint posterior distribution d Π ( β , σ 2 |y ) is such as β |y, σ 2 ∼ N ( μ n , V n σ 2 ) ; σ 2 |y ∼ IG ( a n , k n ) with V n -1 = Φ ⊤ Φ + V 0 -1 ; μ n = V n ( ( Φ ⊤ Φ ) -1 Φ y+ V 0 -1 μ 0 ) ; a n = n 2 + a 0 k n = 1 2 (y- Φ β ˆ n ) ⊤ ( y- Φ β ˆ n ) - 1 2 μ n ⊤ V n -1 μ n + 1 2 ( μ 0 ⊤ V 0 -1 μ 0 + y ⊤ Φ ⊤ ( Φ ⊤ Φ ) -1 Φ y ) + k 0
    Hint-1:
    (y- Φ β ) ⊤ ( y- Φ β ) =( β - β ˆ n ) ⊤ [ Φ ⊤ Φ ] ( β - β ˆ n ) + S n ; S n = (y- Φ β ˆ n ) ⊤ ( y- Φ β ˆ n ) ; β ˆ n = ( Φ ⊤ Φ ) -1 Φ y
    Hint-2:
    If Σ 1 >0 and Σ 2 >0 symmetric - 1 2 ( x- μ 1 ) Σ 1 -1 ( x- μ 1 ) ⊤ - 1 2 ( x- μ 2 ) Σ 2 -1 ( x- μ 2 ) ⊤ =- 1 2 ( x-m ) V -1 ( x-m ) ⊤ +C where V -1 = Σ 1 -1 + Σ 2 -1 ;m=V( Σ 1 -1 μ 1 + Σ 2 -1 μ 2 ) ;C= 1 2 m ⊤ V -1 m- 1 2 ( μ 1 ⊤ Σ 1 -1 μ 1 + μ 2 ⊤ Σ 2 -1 μ 2 )

Exercise 27. ( ★ ★ )
Let y=( y 1 ,..., y n ) be observables drawn iid from sampling distribution y i | θ ∼ iid N ( θ , θ 2 ) for all i=1,...,n , where θ ∈ R is unknown. Specify a conjugate prior density for θ up to an unknown normalizing constant.
Solution. The sampling distribution is f( y i | θ ) = N ( y i | θ , θ 2 ) ∝ ( θ 2 ) -1/2 exp ( - 1 2 ( y i - θ ) 2 θ 2 ) ∝ | θ | -1 exp ( - 1 2 y i 2 1 θ 2 + y i 1 θ ) and hence it belongs to the exponential family with g( θ ) =| θ | -1 , c 1 =- 1 2 , φ 1 ( θ ) = 1 θ 2 , h 1 ( y i ) = y i 2 , c 2 =1 , φ 2 ( θ ) = 1 θ , h 2 ( y i ) = y i .
The corresponding conjugate prior has pdf such as π ( θ ) = π ˜ ( θ | τ ) ∝ | θ | - τ 0 exp ( - 1 2 1 θ 2 τ 1 + 1 θ τ 2 ) , where τ =( τ 0 , τ 1 , τ 2 ) . I actually cannot recognize it as a standard distribution in this case. The posterior distribution has pdf such as π ( θ |y ) ∝ f( y| θ ) π ( θ ) = ∏ i=1 n N ( y i | θ , θ 2 ) π ( θ ) ∝ | θ | -( τ 0 +n ) exp ( - 1 2 1 θ 2 ( τ 1 + ∑ i=1 n y i 2 ) + 1 θ ( τ 2 + ∑ i=1 n y i ) ) Namely, π ( θ |y ) = π ˜ ( θ | τ * ) , with τ *=( τ 0 +n, τ 1 + ∑ i=1 n y i 2 , τ 2 + ∑ i=1 n y i ) ; so it is conjugate.

Solution. It is f( y ) ≤ ∑ ∀ y f( y ) = ∑ ∀ y ∫ f( y| θ ) d Π ( θ ) ⏞ f( y ) = = Fubini ∫ ∑ ∀ y f( y| θ ) d Π ( θ ) = ∫ d Π ( θ ) =1


Exercise 29. ( ★ ★ )
If the sampling distribution F( ⋅ | θ ) is continuous and the prior Π ( θ ) is proper, then the posterior Π ( θ |y ) is almost always proper.
Solution. It is ∫ f( y ) d y= ∫ ∀ y ∫ ∀ θ f( y| θ ) d Π ( θ ) ⏞ f( y ) = d y= Fubini ∫ ∀ θ ∫ ∀ y f( y| θ ) d y d Π ( θ ) = ∫ d Π ( θ ) =1 So it is f( y ) < ∞ for every set of y (possibly) apart from a finite number of y 's with 'probability' zero.


General:
Let integrable functions f( x ) , and g( x ) for x ≥ a .
Let 0 ≤ f( x ) ≤ g( x ) , for x ≥ a Then
∫ a ∞ g( x ) d x< ∞ ⟹ ∫ a ∞ f( x ) d x< ∞ ∫ a ∞ f( x ) d x= ∞ ⟹ ∫ a ∞ g( x ) d x= ∞
Type I:
Let integrable functions f( x ) , and g( x ) for x ≥ a , and let g( x ) be positive.
Let lim n → ∞ f( x ) g( x ) =c Then
  • If c ∈ ( 0, ∞ ) : ∫ a ∞ g( x ) d x< ∞ ⟺ ∫ a ∞ f( x ) d x< ∞
  • If c=0 : ∫ a ∞ g( x ) d x< ∞ ⟹ ∫ a ∞ f( x ) d x< ∞
  • If c= ∞ : ∫ a ∞ f( x ) d x= ∞ ⟹ ∫ a ∞ g( x ) d x= ∞
Type II:
Let integrable functions f( x ) , and g( x ) for a<x ≤ b , and let g( x ) be positive.
Let lim n → a + f( x ) g( x ) =c Then
  • If c ∈ ( 0, ∞ ) : ∫ a ∞ g( x ) d x< ∞ ⟺ ∫ a ∞ f( x ) d x< ∞
  • If c=0 : ∫ a ∞ g( x ) d x< ∞ ⟹ ∫ a ∞ f( x ) d x< ∞
  • If c= ∞ : ∫ a ∞ f( x ) d x= ∞ ⟹ ∫ a ∞ g( x ) d x= ∞
Note:
A useful test function is ∫ 0 ∞ ( 1 x ) p d x{ < ∞ ,  when  p>1 = ∞ ,  when  p ≤ 1

Exercise 33. ( ★ ★ )
Assume that observable quantities x 1 , x 2 ,... are generated i.i.d by a process that can be modeled as a sampling distribution N ( μ , σ 2 ) with known σ 2 and unknown μ .
  1. Assume that you have collected an observation x 1 . Specify a prior Π ( μ ) on μ as μ ∼ N ( μ 0 , σ 0 2 ) where μ 0 , σ 0 2 are known.

    Then the posterior distribution Π ( μ | x 1 , x 2 ) has PDF π ( μ | x 1 , x 2 ) ∝ ( x 2 | μ , σ 2 ) ⏞ likelihood N ( μ | μ ˆ 1 , σ ˆ 1 2 ) ⏞ prior ∝ exp ( - 1 2 ( x 2 - μ ) 2 σ 2 ) exp ( - 1 2 ( μ - μ ˆ 1 ) 2 σ ˆ 1 2 ) ∝ exp ( - 1 2 ( x 2 - μ ) 2 σ 2 - 1 2 ( μ - μ ˆ 1 ) 2 σ ˆ 1 2 ) ∝ exp ( - 1 2 ( μ - μ ˆ 2 ) 2 σ ˆ 2 2 ) ∝ N ( μ | μ ˆ 2 , σ ˆ 2 2 ) (4) where σ ˆ 2 2 =( 1 σ 2 + 1 σ ˆ 1 2 ) -1 =( 1 σ 2 + 1 σ 2 + 1 σ 0 2 ) -1 , and μ ˆ 2 = σ ˆ 1 2 ( x 2 σ 2 + μ ˆ 1 σ ˆ 1 2 ) = σ ˆ 2 2 ( x 1 σ 2 + x 2 σ 2 + μ 0 σ 0 2 ) .   3. It is easy to see that μ ˆ 2 = μ ˆ , and σ ˆ 2 2 = σ ˆ 2 , from (1) and (2). Part V Exchangeability

We work on the proofs of the following theorems:
  • Marginal distributions of finite exchangeable sequences y 1 , y 2 , … , y k are invariant under permutations; i.e.: d F( y p ( 1 ) , y p ( 2 ) , … , y p ( k ) ) = d F( y 1 , y 2 , … , y k )  for all  p ∈ P n . (6) In particular, for k=1 , it follows that all y i are identically distributed (but not necessarily independently, as stated in the Lecture notes)
  • (Marginal) Expectations of finite exchangeable sequences y 1 , y 2 , … , y k are all identical: E ( g( y i ) ) = E ( g( y 1 ) )  for all  i=1,...,k  and all functions  g : Y → R (7)
  • (Marginal) Variances of finite exchangeable sequences y 1 , y 2 , … , y k are all identical: Var ( y i ) = Var ( y 1 ) . (8)
  • Covariances between elements of finite exchangeable sequences y 1 , y 2 , … , y k are all identical: Cov ( y i , y j ) = Cov ( y 1 , y 2 )  whenever  i ≠ j. (9)
Just for your information
The properties above are implied by the following general theorem. However, you should not use this theorem, directly, to solve the exercises below...
Theorem. Consider an exchangeable sequence y 1 , …, y n . Let g : Y k → R be any function of k of these, where k ≤ n . Then, for any permutation π ∈ Π n , E ( g( Y p ( 1 ) , Y p ( 2 ) , … , Y p ( k ) ) ) = E ( g( Y 1 , Y 2 , … , Y k ) ) (10)
This is not an exercise to solve. Feel free to read the solution of this exercise, as it may help you understand the the Interpretation of the `representation Theorem with 0-1 quantities'.
Exercise 34. ( ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ )
(Representation Theorem with 0-1 quantities). If y 1 , y 2 ,... is an infinitely exchangeable sequence of 0-1 random quantities with probability measure P , there exists a distribution function Π such that the joint mass function p( y 1 ,..., y n ) for y 1 ,..., y n has the form p( x 1 ,...,x n ) = ∫ 0 1 ∏ i=1 n θ y i (1- θ ) 1- y i ⏟ f Br ( θ ) ( y i | θ ) d Π ( θ ) where Π ( t ) = lim n → ∞ Pr ( 1 n ∑ i=1 n y i ≤ t ) and θ = as lim n → ∞ 1 n ∑ i=1 n y i aka θ is the limiting relative frequency of 1 s, by SLLN
Hint:
(Helly's theorem [modified]) Given a sequence of distribution functions { F 1 , F 2 ,...} that satisfy the tightness condition; [for each ε >0 there is a such that for all sufficiency large i it is F i ( a ) - F i ( -a ) >1- ε ], there exists a distribution F and a sub-sequence { F i 1 , F i 2 ,...} such that F i j → F .

Solution. Let the sum of random quantities be S n = ∑ i=1 n y i , and assume that the sum S n is equal to value s n ; i.e. S n = t n . By exchangeability, for 0 ≤ t n <n , it is p( S n = t n ) =(n t n )p( y p ( 1 ) ,..., y p ( n ) ) for any permutation operator p . For finite N , let N ≥ n ≥ t n ≥ 0 , p( S n = t n )= ∑ t N =0 N p( S n = t n | S N = t N ) p( S N = t N ) = ∑ t N =0 t n -1 p( S n = t n | S N = t N ) p( S N = t N ) ⏟ =0 (11) + ∑ y N = y n N-( n- y n ) p( S n = t n | S N = t N ) p( S N = t N ) + ∑ t N =N-( n- t n ) +1 N p( S n = t n | S N = t N ) p( S N = t N ) ⏟ =0 (12) = ∑ y N = y n N-( n- y n ) p( S n = t n | S N = t N ) p( S N = t N ) The terms in (12, 12) are zero because p( S n = t n | S N = t N ) =0 for t N < t n and t N >N-( n- t n ) because we contrition on S N = t N .
We work out on p( S n = t n | S N = t N ) which is the conditional probability for S n given S N = t N . We observe that the random variable S n | S N = t N follows a Hypergeometric distribution S n | S N = t N ∼ Hy ( t N ,N- t N ,n ) . This is because it describes a Hypergeometric experiment
2
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypergeometric_distribution
. i.e., S n = t n is the number of successes (random draws for which the object drawn has a specified feature) in n random draws without replacement, from a finite population of size N that contains exactly S N = t N objects of that feature, wherein each draw is either a success or a failure (aka x i =0 or 1 ). Hence, p( S n = t n | S N = t N ) is a Hypergeometric PMF, namely p( S n = t n | S N = t N ) = Hy ( S n = t n | t N ,N- t N ,n ) = ( t N t n )( N- t N n- t n ) (Nn) ,0 ≤ t n ≤ n Rewriting the binomial coefficients by rearranging the terms in the product, we get p( S n = t n ) = ∑ (Nn) -1 ( t N t n )( N- t N n- t n )p( S N = t N ) =(n t n ) ∑ ( t N ) t n (N- t N ) n- t n (N ) n p( S N = t N ) where (y ) r =y( y-1 ) ...( y-r+1 ) .
Now, define a function Π N ( θ ) on R as the step function which is zero for θ <0 , and has steps of size p( S N = t N ) at θ = t N /N for t N =0,1,2,...,N . Then, by changing variable we get, p( S n = t n ) =(n t n ) ∫ 0 1 ( θ N ) (( 1- θ ) N ) n- t n (N ) n d Π N ( θ ) . This result holds for any finite N . Now we need to consider N → ∞ . In the limit, we get lim N → ∞ ( θ N ) (( 1- θ ) N ) n- t n (N ) n = θ t n (1- θ ) n- t n = ∏ i=1 n θ y i (1- θ ) 1- y i (13) Note that function Π N ( t ) is a step function, starting at zero and ending at one with N steps of varying sizes at particular values of t . By Helly's theorem, there exists a subsequence { Π N 1 , Π N 2 ,...} such that lim N j → ∞ Π N j = Π where Π is a distribution function.
Exercise 35. ( ★ ★ )
Clearly a set of independent and identically distributed random variables form an exchangeable sequence. Thus sampling with replacement generates an exchangeable sequence. What about sampling without replacement? Prove that sampling n items from N distinct objects without replacement (where n ≤ N ) is exchangeable.
Solution.  Sampling without replacement is clearly not iid. However, it is exchangeable. Assume that we sample n items from N distinct objects without replacement, we have that: f( y 1 ,..., y n ) = 1 N n ¯ = ( N-n ) ! N! (14) Clearly, the probability mass function does not depend on the ordering of the sequence. Therefore the sequence is exchangeable.

Exercise 37. ( ★ ★ )
Let Y 1 , …, Y n be an exchangeable sequence. Use E ( g( Y i ) ) = E ( g( Y 1 ) )  for all  i ∈ {2, … ,n} (19) to show that Var ( Y i ) does not depend on i : Var ( Y i ) = Var ( Y 1 )  for all  i ∈ {2, … ,n} (20)
Solution. By the usual properties of variance, Var ( Y i ) = E ( Y i 2 ) - E ( Y i ) 2 (21) and now applying19 twice
Var ( Y i ) = E ( Y 1 2 ) - E ( Y 1 ) 2 = Var ( Y 1 )
Exercise 38. ( ★ ★ )
Let Y 1 , …, Y n be an exchangeable sequence. By expanding var ( ∑ k=1 n Y k ) , show that when i ≠ j , cov ( Y i , Y j ) ≥ - var ( Y 1 ) n-1 (22)
Solution.   It is
where the n 2 -n factor can be derived as follows: note that the pairs of indices ( k, ℓ ) appearing in the sum can be put into a matrix—the sum does not include the diagonal of this matrix ( n pairs), but otherwise covers precisely half of it, and the full matrix has n 2 pairs, so there are ( n 2 -n ) /2 terms in the sum.

Exercise 39. ( ★ )
What does cov ( Y i , Y j ) ≥ - var ( Y 1 ) n-1 imply about the correlation of infinite exchangeable sequences?
Solution.   The correlation must be non-negative: because, as n → ∞ , cov ( Y i , Y j ) ≥ 0 for all i ≠ j .

Exercise 40. ( ★ ★ )
Consider the Bayesian model { x i | θ ∼ iid Ex ( θ ) , ∀ i=1,...,n θ ∼ Ga ( a,b )
Hint-1:
The PDF of x ∼ G ( a,b ) is Ga ( x|a,b ) = b a Γ ( a ) x a-1 exp ( -bx ) 1 ( 0,+ ∞ ) ( x )
Hint-2:
The PDF of x ∼ Ex ( θ ) is Ex ( x| θ ) = Ga ( x|1, θ )
  1. Show that the parametric model is member of the Exponential family, and the sufficient statistic for a sample of observables x=( x 1 ,..., x n ) .
  2. Show that the posterior distribution θ given x is Gamma and compute its parameters.
  3. Show that the predictive distribution G( z|x ) of a future z given x=( x 1 ,..., x n ) , has PDF g( z|x ) = a * ( b * ) a * (z+ b * ) a * +1 1 ( x ≥ 0 )

The parametric model is Ex ( x| θ ) = θ exp ( - θ x ) 1 ( x ≥ 0 ) It is member of the exponential family Ef 1 ( x|u,g,h,c, φ , θ ,c ) =u( x ) g( θ ) exp ( ∑ j=1 k c j φ j ( θ ) h j ( x ) ) with u( x 1:n ) =1 , g( θ ) = θ , c 1 =-1 , φ 1 ( θ ) = θ , h 1 ( x ) =x . The sufficient statistic is t n =( n, ∑ i=1 n x i ) .
  2. I can get the posterior by using the Bayes theorem π ( θ |x ) ∝ f( x| θ ) π ( θ |a,b ) ∝ ∏ i=1 n Ex ( x i | θ ) Ga ( θ |a,b ) ∝ θ n exp ( - θ ∑ i=1 n x i ) θ a-1 exp ( - θ b ) ∝ θ a+n-1 exp ( - θ ( ∑ i=1 n x i +b ) ) ∝ Ga ( θ | a+n ⏟ = a * , b+ ∑ i=1 n x i ⏟ = b * )
  3. By using the definition of the predictive distribution, it is ... g( z|x ) = ∫ R + f( z| θ ) π ( θ |x ) d θ = z ≥ 0 ∫ R + θ exp ( - θ z ) ( b * ) a * Γ ( a * ) θ a * -1 exp ( - θ b * ) d θ = ( b * ) a * Γ ( a * ) ∫ R + θ a * +1-1 exp ( - θ ( z+ b * ) ) d θ = ( b * ) a * Γ ( a * ) Γ ( a * +1 ) (z+ b * ) a * +1 = a * ( b * ) a * (z+ b * ) a * +1 = a * ( b * ) a * (z+ b * ) a * +1
Exercise 41. ( ★ ★ ★ )
Consider the Bayesian model { x i | θ ∼ IID Mu k ( θ ) θ ∼ Di k ( a ) where θ ∈ Θ , with Θ ={ θ ∈ (0,1 ) k | ∑ j=1 k θ j =1} and X k ={x ∈ {0,...,n } k | ∑ j=1 k x j =1} .
Hint-1:
Mu k denotes the Multinomial probability distribution with PMF Mu k ( x| θ ) ={ ∏ j=1 k θ j x j , if x ∈ X k 0 , otherwise (26)
Hint-2:
Di k ( a ) denotes the Dirichlet distribution with PDF Di k ( θ |a ) ={ Γ ( ∑ j=1 k a j ) ∏ j=1 k Γ ( a j ) ∏ j=1 k θ j a j -1 , if θ ∈ Θ 0 , otherwise
  1. Show that the parametric model (26) is a member of the k-1 exponential family.
  2. Compute the likelihood f( x 1:n | θ ) , and find the sufficient statistic t n := t n ( x 1:n ) .
  3. Compute the posterior distribution. State the name of the distribution, and expresses its parameters with respect to the observations and the hyper-parameters of the prior. Justify your answer.
  4. Compute the probability mass function of the predictive distribution for a future observation y= x n+1 in closed form.
    Hint
    Γ ( x ) =( x-1 ) Γ ( x-1 ) .
Solution.  
  1. There are k-1 independent parameters in Mu k ( θ ) because ∑ j=1 k θ j =1 . I consider as parameters ( θ 1 ,..., θ k-1 ) and the last one is a function of them as θ k =1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j .
    It is Mu k ( x| θ ) = ∏ j=1 k θ j x j = ∏ j=1 k-1 θ j x j (1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j ) 1- ∑ j=1 k-1 x j =( 1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j ) exp ( ∑ j=1 k-1 x j log ( θ j 1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j ) ) This is the k-1 exponential family PDF with u( x ) =1; g( θ ) =( 1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j ) ; c =( 1,...,1 ) h( x ) =( x 1 ,... x k-1 ) ; φ ( θ ) =( log ( θ 1 1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j ) ,..., log ( θ k-1 1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j ) ) ,
  2. The likelihood is f( x 1:n | θ ) = ∏ i=1 n Mu k ( x i | θ ) = ∏ j=1 k θ j ∑ i=1 n x i,j = ∏ j=1 k θ j x *,j =(1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j ) n exp ( ∑ j=1 k-1 x *,j log ( θ j 1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j ) ) and the sufficient statistic is t n =( n, x *,1 ,..., x *,k-1 )
  3. It is π ( θ | x 1:n ) = ∏ i=1 n Mu k ( x i | θ ) Di k ( θ |a ) ∝ ∏ j=1 k θ j x *,j ∏ j=1 k θ j a j -1 = ∏ j=1 k θ j x j + a *,j -1 ∝ Di k ( θ | a ˜ ) where a ˜ =( a ˜ 1 ,..., a ˜ k ) , with a ˜ j = a j + x *,j for j=1,...,k . So the posterior is θ | x 1:n ∼ Di k ( a ˜ ) .
  4. It is p( y| x 1:n ) = ∫ Mu k ( y| θ ) Di k ( θ | a ˜ ) d θ = ∫ ∏ j=1 k θ j y j Γ ( ∑ j=1 k a ˜ j ) ∏ j=1 k Γ ( a ˜ j ) ∏ j=1 k θ j a j ˜ -1 d θ = Γ ( ∑ j=1 k a ˜ j ) ∏ j=1 k Γ ( a ˜ j ) ∫ ∏ j=1 k θ j y j + a ˜ j -1 d θ = Γ ( ∑ j=1 k a ˜ j ) ∏ j=1 k Γ ( a ˜ j ) ∏ j=1 k Γ ( y j + a ˜ j ) Γ ( ∑ j=1 k ( y j + a ˜ j ) ) = Γ ( ∑ j=1 k ( a j + x *,j ) ) ∏ j=1 k Γ ( a j + x *,j ) ∏ j=1 k Γ ( y j + a j + x *,j ) Γ ( ∑ j=1 k ( y j + a j + x *,j ) ) = Γ ( a * + x *,* ) ∏ j=1 k Γ ( a j + x *,j ) ∏ j=1 k Γ ( y j + a j + x *,j ) Γ ( ∑ j=1 k y j + a * + x *,* ) = Γ ( a * +n ) ∏ j=1 k Γ ( a j + x *,j ) ∏ j=1 k Γ ( y j + a j + x *,j ) Γ ( 1+ a * +n ) = Γ ( n+ a * ) Γ ( 1+ a * +n ) ∏ j=1 k Γ ( y j + a j + x *,j ) Γ ( a j + x *,j ) so p( y| x 1:n ) = 1 n+ a * ( a j' + x *,j' ) , where j' such that y j' =1 .
Exercise 42. ( ★ ★ )
Suppose that the vector [font bf [char x mathalpha]] =( x,y,z ) has a trinomial distribution depending on the index n and the parameter [font bf [symbol varpi]] =( π , ρ , σ ) where π + ρ + σ =1 , that is p( [font bf [char x mathalpha]] | [font bf [symbol varpi]] ) = n! x!y!z! π x ρ y σ z ( x+y+z=n ) . Exercise 43. ( ★ )
Establish the formula ( n 0 -1 + n -1 ) -1 ( x ‾ - θ 0 ) 2 =n x ‾ 2 + n 0 θ 0 2 - n 1 θ 1 2 where n 1 = n 0 +n and θ 1 =( n 0 θ 0 +n x ‾ ) / n 1 .
This formula is often used to 'complete the square' in quadratiforms.

The following is a proof of a theorem
Exercise 44. ( ★ ★ ★ )
Let y 1 , y 2 ... be an infinitely exchangeable sequence of random quantities. Let t=t( y 1 ,..., y n ) be a statistic for a finite n ≥ 1 . Then t is predictive sufficient if, and only if, it is parametric sufficient.
Solution. Let Y ( t ) ={y:t=t( y ) } , and let z=( y n+1 ,..., y n+m ) then p( z|t ) = p( z,t ) p( t ) = ∫ Y ( t ) p( y n+1:n+m , y 1:n ) d y 1:n p( t ) ( repr.theor. ) = 1 p( t ) ∫ Y ( t ) [ ∫ Θ ∏ i=1 n+m f( y i | θ ) d Π ( θ ) ] d y 1:n = 1 p( t ) ∫ Θ [ ∫ Y ( t ) ∏ i=n+1 n+m f( y i | θ ) ∏ i=1 n f( y i | θ ) d y 1 ⋯ d y n ] d Π ( θ ) = 1 p( t ) ∫ Θ ∏ i=n+1 n+m f( y i | θ ) f( t| θ ) d Π ( θ ) = ∫ Θ ∏ i=n+1 n+m f( y i | θ ) f( t| θ ) d Π ( θ ) p( t ) ⏟ = d Π ( θ |t ) = ∫ Θ ∏ i=n+1 n+m f( y i | θ ) d Π ( θ |t ) . So p( z|t ) = ∫ Θ ∏ i=n+1 n+m f( y i | θ ) d Π ( θ |t ) ; p( z|y ) = ∫ Θ ∏ i=n+1 n+m f( y i | θ ) d Π ( θ |y ) Therefore, we have parametric sufficiency p( z|t ) =p( z|y ) if and only if d Π ( θ |t ) = d Π ( θ |y ) for all d Π ( θ ) .
The following is a proof of a theorem
Exercise 45. ( ★ ★ ★ )
(This is a theorem in Handout 5) Prove the following statement.
Let t: Y → T be a statistic. Then t is a parametric sufficient statistic for θ in the Bayesian sense if and only if the likelihood function L( ⋅ | ⋅ ) on Y × Θ can be factorized as the product of a kernel function k on Y × Θ and a residue function ρ on Θ as L( y; θ ) =k( t( y ) | θ ) ρ ( y ) . (27)
Solution.  
( ⟸ )
I need to show that for any set Θ ' ⊆ Θ it is Π ( Θ '|y ) = Π ( Θ '|t ) , where t=t( y ) .
For any Θ ' and Y' , it is Π ( Θ '|Y' ) = ∫ Π ( Θ '|y ) d F( y|Y' ) = E y|Y' ( Π ( Θ '|y ) |Y' ) Let's take Y '= Y ( t ) ={y:t( y ) =t'} for some t' .
It is Π ( Θ '|y=y' ) = Π ( Θ '| Y ' ) = E y|Y' ( Π ( θ |y ) = E y| Y ' ( ∫ Θ ' d Π ( θ |y ) ) = E y| Y ' ( ∫ Θ ' L( y; θ ) d Π ( θ ) ∫ Θ L( y; θ ) d Π ( θ ) | Y ' ) = E y| Y ' ( ∫ Θ ' k( t( y ) | θ ) ρ ( y ) d Π ( θ ) ∫ Θ k( t( y ) | θ ) ρ ( y ) d Π ( θ ) | Y ' ) = E y| Y ' ( ∫ Θ ' k( t( y ) | θ ) d Π ( θ ) ∫ Θ k( t( y ) | θ ) d Π ( θ ) |Y' ) Because the fraction inside the expectation is the same for all values y ∈ Y ' , we may suppress it. So Π ( Θ '|y ) = ∫ Θ ' k( t( y ) | θ ) d Π ( θ ) ∫ Θ k( t( y ) | θ ) d Π ( θ ) = Π ( Θ '|t )
( ) I ll construct a `kernel' κ ( y| θ ) invariant for each y ∈ Y ( t ) where Y ( t ) ={y:t( y ) =t} . I set κ ( y| θ ) = f( y| θ ) f( y ) ; ρ ( y ) = f( y ) ; (28) so by Bayes theorem π ( θ |y ) = f( y| θ ) π ( θ ) f( y ) = π ( θ ) f( y| θ ) f( y ) = π ( θ ) κ ( y| θ ) Because t is parametric sufficient for any y,y' ∈ Y ( t ) ={y:t( y ) =t} it is π ( θ |y ) = π ( θ |t ) = π ( θ |y' ) so π ( θ |y ) = π ( θ |y' ) ⟹ π ( θ ) κ ( y| θ ) = π ( θ ) κ ( y'| θ ) ⟹ π ( θ ) ≠ 0 κ ( y| θ ) = κ ( y'| θ ) From every t ∈ T I choose one y ∈ Y ( t ) , I set k( t| θ ) = κ ( y| θ ) , and I substitute it in (28), so I get κ ( y| θ ) = f( y| θ ) f( y ) ⟹ f( y| θ ) = κ ( y| θ ) f( y ) ⟹ f( y| θ ) =k( t( y ) | θ ) ρ ( y )

Part VII Priors

Exercise 46. ( ★ ★ )
Let y=( y 1 ,..., y n ) be observable quantities, generated from an exponential family of distributions as y i | θ ∼ iid Ef ( u,g,h,c, φ , θ ,c ) ,i=1,...,n with density Ef ( y i |u,g,h,c, φ , θ ,c ) =u( y i ) g( θ ) n exp ( ∑ j=1 k c j φ j ( θ ) h j ( y i ) ) and assume a conjugate prior Π ( θ ) with pdf/pmf π ( θ ) = π ˜ ( θ | τ ) ∝ g( θ ) τ 0 exp ( ∑ j=1 k c j φ j ( θ ) τ j )
  1. Show that the posterior Π ( θ |y ) of θ has pdf/pmf π ( θ |y ) = π ˜ ( θ | τ * ) with τ * =( τ 0 * , τ 1 * ,..., τ k * ) , τ 0 * = τ 0 +n , and τ j * = ∑ i=1 n h j ( x i ) + τ j for j=1,...,k , and pdf/pmf π ( θ |y ) = π ( θ | τ * ) ∝ g( θ ) τ * exp ( ∑ j=1 k c j φ j ( θ ) τ j * ) (29) The operation * here is addition
  2. Show that the predictive distribution G( z|y ) for a new outcome z=( y n+1 ,..., y n+m ) has pdf/ pmf g( z|y ) = ∏ i=1 m u( z i ) K( τ +t( y ) +t( z ) ) K( τ + t n ( y ) ) (30) where t( z ) =( m, ∑ i=1 m h 1 ( z i ) ,..., ∑ i=1 m h k ( z i ) ) .
Solution.  
  1. According to the Bayes theorem, where π ( θ |y ) ∝ f( y| θ ) π ( θ ) ∝ g( θ ) n exp ( ∑ j=1 k c j φ j ( θ ) ( ∑ i=1 n h j ( y i ) ) ) ) g( θ ) τ 0 exp ( ∑ j=1 k c j φ j ( θ ) τ j ) ∝ g( θ ) n+ τ 0 exp ( ∑ j=1 k c j φ j ( θ ) ( ∑ i=1 n h j ( y i ) + τ j ) ) ) ∝ π ˜ ( θ |y, τ +t( y ) ) .
  2. According to the predictive pdf/pmf equation, and assuming that θ is a continuous random quantity, it is g( z|y ) = ∫ Θ ∏ l=1 m f( z l | θ ) π ( θ |y ) d θ = ∫ Θ ∏ l=1 m u( z l ) g( θ ) m exp ( ∑ j=1 k c j φ j ( θ ) ( ∑ l=1 m h j ( z l ) ) ) ) × 1 K( τ +t( y ) ) g( θ ) n+ τ 0 exp ( ∑ j=1 k c j φ j ( θ ) ( ∑ i=1 n h j ( y i ) + τ j ) ) ) d θ = ∏ l=1 m u( z l ) 1 K( τ + t n ( y ) ) ∫ Θ g( θ ) n+m+ τ 0 exp ( ∑ j=1 k c j φ j ( θ ) ( ∑ l=1 m h j ( z l ) + ∑ i=1 n h j ( y i ) + τ j ) ) ) d ⏟ =K( τ +t( y ) +t( z ) ) θ For the case where θ is a discrete random quantity, the proof is similar.
Exercise 47. ( ★ ★ )
 
  1. Show that the skew-logistic family of distributions, with f( x| θ ) = θ e -x (1+ e -x ) θ +1 (31) for x ∈ R , labeled by θ >0 , is a member of the exponential family and identify the factors u,g,h, φ , θ ,c .
  2. Show that the Gamma distribution f( θ | α 0 , β 0 ) = β 0 α 0 Γ ( α 0 ) θ α 0 -1 e - β 0 θ (32) with hyperparameters w 0 ≔ ( α 0 , β 0 ) (where α 0 >1 and β 0 >0 ) is conjugate for i.i.d. sampling from for the skew-logistic distribution. Relate the hyperparameters ( τ 0 , τ 1 ) to the standard parameters ( α 0 , β 0 ) of the gamma distribution.
  3. Given an i.i.d. sample x 1 , …, x n from the skew-logistic distribution, and assuming that the prior is Gamma ( α 0 , β 0 ) , derive the posterior distribution of θ .
  4. Given an i.i.d. sample x 1 , …, x n from the skew-logistic distribution, and assuming that the prior is Gamma ( α 0 , β 0 ) , derive the predictive PDF for a future y= x n+1 up to a normalising constant.
  5. Give a minimal sufficient statistic for θ under i.i.d. sampling from the skew-logistic distribution. Would this statistic still be sufficient if we had chosen a prior for θ which was not a Gamma distribution?
Solution.  
  1.  It is f( x| θ ) = θ e -x (1+ e -x ) θ +1 = e -x θ 1 ( 1+ e -x ) exp ( - θ log ( 1+ e -x ) ) = e -x θ exp ( - θ log ( 1+ e -x ) ) = e -x ( 1+ e -x ) θ exp ( - θ log ( 1+ e -x ) ) So it is a member of the exponential distribution family Ef k ( x|u,g,h, φ , θ ,c ) =u( x ) g( θ ) exp ( ∑ j=1 k c j φ j ( θ ) h j ( x ) ) with k=1 , and u( x ) = e -x ( 1+ e -x ) , g( θ ) = θ , h( x ) = log ( 1+ e -x ) , φ ( θ ) = θ , c =-1.
  2. Following the corresponding theorem, π ( θ | τ ) ∝ g( θ ) τ 0 exp ( ∑ j=1 k c j φ j ( θ ) τ j ) ∝ θ τ 0 exp ( -1 θ τ 1 ) ∝ θ ( τ 0 +1 ) -1 exp ( - θ τ 1 ) where we recognize the Gamma PDF which identifies a Gamma distribution θ | τ ∼ Ga ( τ 0 +1, τ 1 ) .
    Also K( τ ) = ∫ R + g( θ ) τ 0 exp ( ∑ j=1 k φ j ( θ ) τ j ) d θ = ∫ R + θ τ 0 exp ( - θ τ 1 ) d θ = Γ ( τ 0 +1 ) τ 1 τ 0 +1 since ∫ R + Ga ( θ | τ 0 +1, τ 1 ) d θ =1 . To easy the notation with θ | τ ∼ Ga ( a,b ) , we can set ( a,b ) =( τ 0 +1, τ 1 ) .
  3. By using the Bayes theorem π ( θ | x 1:n ) ∝ f( x 1:n | θ ) π ( θ |a,b ) ∝ ∏ i=1 n f( x i | θ ) Ga ( θ |a,b ) ∝ θ n exp ( - θ ∑ i=1 n log ( 1+ e - x i ) ) θ a-1 exp ( - θ b ) ∝ θ a+n-1 exp ( - θ ( ∑ i=1 n log ( 1+ e - x i ) +b ) ) ∝ Ga ( θ | a+n ⏟ = a * , b+ ∑ i=1 n log ( 1+ e - x i ) ⏟ = b * )
  4. By using the definition for the predictive PDF, it is f( y| x 1:n ) = ∫ R + f( y| θ ) Ga ( θ | a * , b * ) d θ ∝ ∫ R + e -y ( 1+ e -y ) θ exp ( - θ log ( 1+ e -y ) ) θ a * -1 exp ( - θ b * ) d θ ∝ e -y ( 1+ e -y ) ∫ R + θ a * +1-1 exp ( - θ ( b * + log ( 1+ e -y ) ) ) d θ ∝ e -y ( 1+ e -y ) Γ ( a * +1 ) ( b * + log ( 1+ e -y ) ) a * +1 ∝ e -y ( 1+ e -y ) 1 ( b * + log ( 1+ e -y ) ) a * +1
  5. Because the parametric model is member of the exponential family, the minimal sufficient statistic is ( n, ∑ i=1 n h( x i ) ) =( n, ∑ i=1 n log ( 1+ e - x i ) ) . By the Neyman factorisation theorem sufficiency only depends on the likelihood: it does not depend on our choice of prior.
The exercise below is theoretical, and very challenging.
Exercise 48. ( ★ ★ ★ )
Prove the following statement.
Consider a PDF/PMF f( x| θ ) with x ∈ X and θ ∈ Θ where X does not depend on θ . If there exist a parametrised conjugate prior family F =( π ( θ | τ ) , τ ∈ T ) with dim ( Λ ) < ∞ , then f( x| τ ) is number of the exponential family.
Hint:
  Use the Pitman-Koopman Lemma:
Lemma. (Pitman-Koopman Lemma) If a family of distributions is such that for a large enough sample size there exist a sufficient statistic of constant dimension, then the family is an exponential family if the support does not depend on θ .
PS:
Please think about the importance of this result (!!!)
Solution.  Assume ∃ F s.t. F =( π ( θ | τ ) , τ ∈ T ) , with dim ( T ) < ∞ . Let's take π ( θ | τ ) as a (conjugate) prior. Then the posterior is π ( θ | x 1:n ) ∝ f( x 1:n | θ ) π ( θ | τ ) . Due to the conjugacy ∃ τ * ( x 1:n ) s.t. π ( θ | τ * ( x 1:n ) ) = f( x 1:n | θ ) π ( θ | τ ) p( x 1:n ) ⟺ f( x 1:n | θ ) = π ( θ | τ * ( x 1:n ) ) π ( θ | τ ) ⏟ =h( τ * ( x 1:n ) , θ ) p( x 1:n ) ⏟ =g( x 1:n ) Due to Newman factorisation criterion τ * ( x 1:n ) is a sufficient statistic, and its dimentionality does not depend on θ . Then because of the Pitman-Koopman Lemma, the f( x 1:n | θ ) is a member of the exponential family.
  • Before that, we knew that parametric models which are members of the exponential family have conjugate priors. The result above says that if there is a conjugate prior for a parametric model whose sample space does not depend on the unknown parameter, then the parametric model is member of the exponential family. Of course it does not apply to Uniform or Pareto parametric models whose sample space depends on the unknown parameter.
Exercise 49. ( ★ ★ )
Suppose that you have a prior distribution for the probability θ of success in a certain kind of gambling game which has mean 0.4 , and that you regard your prior information as equivalent to 12 trials. You then play the game 25 times and win 12 times. What is your posterior distribution for θ ?
Solution. I will make Bayesian Statistical Inference. The parametric model is the Bernoulli distribution, because the experiment is a Bernoulli experiment. The limiting frequency of successes, aka θ ∈ ( 0,1 ) is the uncertain parameter for which I want to perform inference. To account uncertainty about the unknown parameter θ , I will assign a prior distribution. For my computational convenience, I will try to see if there exist a conjugate prior. If it exists, I will assign a conjugate prior for θ . So...
Consider the Bayesian model { x i | θ ∼ iid Br ( θ ) , ∀ i=1:n θ ∼ Π ( θ ) where θ ∈ R .
  • I will try to find a conjugate prior in order to do it
    The likelihood is such that f( x 1:n | θ ) = ∏ i=1 n Br ( x i | θ ) = ∏ i=1 n θ x i (1- θ ) 1- x i =(1- θ ) n exp ( log ( θ 1- θ ) ∑ i=1 n x i ) The parametric model f( ⋅ | θ ) is the Bernoulli distribution which belongs to the exponential family with u( x ) =1 , g( θ ) =( 1- θ ) , c 1 =1 , φ 1 ( θ ) = log ( θ 1- θ ) , h 1 ( x ) =x .
    The corresponding conjugate prior has pdf such as π ( θ | τ ) =K( τ ) (1- θ ) τ 0 exp ( log ( θ 1- θ ) τ 1 ) =K( τ ) θ ( τ 1 +1 ) -1 (1- θ ) ( τ 0 - τ 1 +1 ) -1 where K( τ ) = ∫ 0 1 θ ( τ 1 +1 ) -1 (1- θ ) ( τ 0 - τ 1 +1 ) -1 d θ = Γ ( τ 1 +1 ) Γ ( τ 0 - τ 1 +1 ) Γ ( τ 0 +2 )
    Since we recognize that the prior distribution is Beta, we perform a re-parametrization, as π ( θ | τ ) = Be ( θ |a,b ) where a= τ 1 +1 , b= τ 0 - τ 1 +1 .
  • According to my prior info:
    • my prior info worth 12 trials, so the effective number of observations that the prior distribution contributes is τ 0 =12 ,
    • the a priori mean of θ is 0.4 , so E ( θ ) = a a+b =0.4 . So
      • a+b=( τ 1 +1 ) +( τ 0 - τ 1 +1 ) = τ 0 +2=14
      • a a+b =0.4 ⟺ a=5.6 and b=8.4
  • By using the Bayes theorem, or the theorem about the conjugate posteriors of parametric models in Exponential family, I get a posterior θ | x 1:n ∼ Be ( ∑ i=1 n x i +a ⏟ = a * , n- ∑ i=1 n x i +b ⏟ = b * ) ≡ Be ( 12+5.6,13+8.4 ) ≡ Be ( 17.6,21.4 )
Exercise 50. ( ★ ★ )
Find a (two-dimensional) sufficient statistic for ( α , β ) given an n -sample x=( x 1 , x 2 , … , x n ) from the two-parameter gamma distribution p( x| α , β ) ={ β α Γ ( α ) } -1 x α -1 exp ( -x/ β ) ( 0<x< ∞ ) where the parameters α and β can take any values in 0< α < ∞ , 0< β < ∞ .
Solution. Because p( x| α , β ) = 1 β α Γ ( α ) x α -1 exp ( -x/ β ) = 1 β α Γ ( α ) exp ( -1x/ β +1( a-1 ) log ( x ) ) it belongs to the exponential family, the sufficient statistic is ( n, ∑ i=1 n x i , ∑ i=1 n log ( x i ) ) or equivalently ( n, ∑ i=1 n x i , ∏ i=1 n x i ) .
Exercise 51. ( ★ ★ )
Suppose that your prior for θ with PDF π ( θ ) = 2 3 N ( θ |0,1 ) + 1 3 N ( θ |1,1 ) that a single observation x ∼ N ( θ ,1 ) turns out to equal 2 . What is your posterior probability that θ >1 ?
Hint   
We should use the following identity, discussed in the Lecture notes, : - 1 2 ∑ i=1 n (y- μ i ) 2 σ i 2 =- 1 2 (y- μ ˆ ) 2 σ ˆ 2 +c( μ ˆ , σ ˆ 2 ) , c( μ ˆ , σ ˆ 2 ) =- 1 2 ∑ i=1 n μ i 2 σ i 2 + 1 2 ( ∑ i=1 n μ i σ i 2 ) 2 ( ∑ i=1 n 1 σ i 2 ) -1 ; σ ˆ 2 =( ∑ i=1 n 1 σ i 2 ) -1 ; μ ˆ = σ ˆ 2 ( ∑ i=1 n μ i σ i 2 ) where c( μ ˆ , σ ˆ 2 ) is constant w.r.t. y .
Solution.  The prior is of the form π ( θ ) = ϖ 1 N ( θ | μ 1 ,1 ) + ϖ 2 N ( θ | μ 2 ,1 ) where ϖ 1 =2/3 , ϖ 2 =1/3 , μ 1 =0 , and μ 2 =1 .
  • The posterior pdf will be of the form π ( θ |x=2 ) = ϖ 1 * π 1 ( θ |x=2 ) + ϖ 2 * π 2 ( θ |x=2 ) with each component computed as follows.
  • For the components of the mixture: For the 1 st component, it is π 1 ( θ |x=2 ) ∝ f( x| θ ) π 1 ( θ ) ∝ N ( x| θ ,1 ) N ( θ | μ 1 ,1 ) ∝ exp ( - 1 2 (x- θ ) 2 1 ) exp ( - 1 2 ( θ - μ 1 ) 2 1 ) = exp ( - 1 2 ( θ -x ) 2 1 - 1 2 ( θ - μ 1 ) 2 1 ) ∝ Hint exp ( - 1 2 ( θ - μ ˆ 1 ) 2 σ ˆ 1 2 ) ∝ N ( θ | μ ˆ 1 , σ ˆ 1 2 ) where σ ˆ 1 2 =1/2 μ 1 ˆ = x+ μ 1 2 =1 , because of x=2 , and μ 1 =0 , and Hint . So π 1 ( θ |x=2 ) = N ( θ |1,1/2 ) .
    For the 2 nd component, it is π 2 ( θ |x=2 ) ∝ f( x| θ ) π 2 ( θ ) ∝ N ( x| θ ,1 ) N ( θ | μ 2 ,1 ) ∝ exp ( - 1 2 (x- θ ) 2 1 ) exp ( - 1 2 ( θ - μ 2 ) 2 1 ) = exp ( - 1 2 ( θ -x ) 2 1 - 1 2 ( θ - μ 2 ) 2 1 ) ∝ Hint exp ( - 1 2 ( θ - μ ˆ 2 ) 2 σ ˆ 2 2 ) ∝ N ( θ | μ ˆ 2 , σ ˆ 2 2 ) where σ ˆ 2 2 =1/2 , μ 2 ˆ = x+ μ 2 2 = 3 2 , because of x=2 , μ 2 =1 , and Hint .
    So π 2 ( θ |x=2 ) = N ( θ |3/2,1/2 )
  • For the posterior weights, it is ϖ 1 * = ϖ 1 f 1 ( x ) ϖ 1 f 1 ( x ) + ϖ 2 f 2 ( x ) ; ϖ 2 * = ϖ 2 f 2 ( x ) ϖ 1 f 1 ( x ) + ϖ 2 f 2 ( x ) ; So, I compute f 1 ( x ) = ∫ f( x| θ ) π 1 ( θ ) d θ = ∫ N ( x| θ ,1 ) N ( θ | μ 1 ,1 ) d θ = ∫ 1 2 π exp ( - 1 2 ( θ -x ) 2 1 ) 1 2 π exp ( - 1 2 ( θ - μ 1 ) 2 1 ) d θ = 1 2 π ∫ exp ( - 1 2 ( θ -x ) 2 1 - 1 2 ( θ - μ 1 ) 2 1 ) d θ = Hint 1 2 π ∫ exp (- 1 2 ( θ - μ ˆ 1 ) 2 σ ˆ 1 2 - 1 2 ( x 2 1 + μ 1 2 1 ) + 1 2 (x+ μ 1 ) 2 ( 1 1 + 1 1 ) -1 ) d θ = 1 2 π ∫ exp ( - 1 2 ( θ - μ ˆ 1 ) 2 σ ˆ 1 2 ) d θ ⏟ = 2 π σ ˆ 1 2 exp ( - 1 2 ( x 2 + μ 1 2 ) + 1 2 (x+ μ 1 ) 2 2 ) = 1 2 π 2 π σ ˆ 1 2 exp (- 1 2 ( x 2 + μ 1 2 ) + 1 4 ( x+ μ 1 ) 2 ) = 1 2 π exp (- 1 2 ( 2 2 + 1 2 ) + 1 4 ( 2+1 ) 2 ) because of Hint , μ ˆ 1 = x+ μ 1 2 =1 , σ ˆ 1 2 =1/2 , x=2 , μ 1 =0 . Hence, f 1 ( x=2 ) = 1 2 π exp ( -1 ) ≈ 0.10. Also, I compute f 2 ( x ) = ∫ f( x| θ ) π 2 ( θ ) d θ = ∫ N ( x| θ ,1 ) N ( θ | μ 2 ,1 ) d θ = ∫ 1 2 π exp ( - 1 2 ( θ -x ) 2 1 ) 1 2 π exp ( - 1 2 ( θ - μ 2 ) 2 1 ) d θ = 1 2 π ∫ exp ( - 1 2 ( θ -x ) 2 1 - 1 2 ( θ - μ 2 ) 2 1 ) d θ = Hint 1 2 π ∫ exp (- 1 2 ( θ - μ ˆ 2 ) 2 σ ˆ 2 2 - 1 2 ( x 2 1 + μ 2 2 1 ) + 1 2 (x+ μ 2 ) 2 ( 1 1 + 1 1 ) -1 ) d θ = 1 2 π ∫ exp ( - 1 2 ( θ - μ ˆ 2 ) 2 σ ˆ 2 2 ) d θ ⏟ = 2 π σ ˆ 2 2 exp ( - 1 2 ( x 2 + μ 2 2 ) + 1 2 (x+ μ 2 ) 2 2 ) = 1 2 π 2 π σ ˆ 2 2 exp (- 1 2 ( x 2 + μ 2 2 ) + 1 4 ( x+ μ 2 ) 2 ) = 1 2 π exp (- 1 2 ( 2 2 +( 3 2 ) 2 ) + 1 4 ( 2+ 3 2 ) 2 ) because of Hint , and μ ˆ 2 = x+ μ 2 2 = 3 2 , σ ˆ 2 2 =1/2 , since x=2 , μ 2 =1 . Hence, f 2 ( x=2 ) = 1 2 π exp ( - 1 4 ) ≈ 0.22 So ϖ 1 * = ϖ 1 f 1 ( x=2 ) ϖ 1 f 1 ( x=2 ) + ϖ 2 f 2 ( x=2 ) = 2 exp ( -1 ) 2 exp ( -1 ) + exp ( -1/4 ) ≈ 0.48 ϖ 2 * = ϖ 2 f 2 ( x=2 ) ϖ 1 f 1 ( x=2 ) + ϖ 2 f 2 ( x=2 ) = exp ( -1/4 ) 2 exp ( -1 ) + exp ( -1/4 ) ≈ 0.52
  • The posterior becomes π ( θ |x=2 ) = ϖ 1 * N ( θ |1,1/2 ) + ϖ 2 * N ( θ |3/2,1/2 )
  • It is π ( θ >1|x=2 ) =1- π ( θ ≤ 1|x=2 ) =1- ∫ - ∞ 1 π ( θ |x=2 ) d θ =1- ϖ 1 * ∫ - ∞ 1 π 1 ( θ |x=2 ) d θ - ϖ 2 * ∫ - ∞ 1 π 2 ( θ |x=2 ) d θ =1- ϖ 1 * ∫ - ∞ 1 N ( θ |1, 1 2 ) d θ - ϖ 2 * ∫ - ∞ 1 N ( θ | 3 2 , 1 2 ) d θ =1- ϖ 1 * Φ ( 0 1/2 ) - ϖ 2 * Φ ( - 1/2 ) =1- ϖ 1 * Φ ( 0 ) - ϖ 2 * Φ ( - 1/2 ) ≈ 0.63

Exercise 52. ( ★ ★ )
Let x=( x 1 ,..., x n ) be observables. Consider a Bayesian model such as { x i | λ ∼ iid Pn ( λ ) , ∀ i=1,...,n λ ∼ Π ( λ )
Hint-1
Poisson distribution x ∼ Pn ( λ ) has PMF: Pn ( x| λ ) = 1 x! λ x exp ( - λ ) 1 N ( x ) , where N ={0,1,2,...} and λ >0 .
Hint-2
Gamma distribution x ∼ Ga ( a,b ) has PDF: Ga ( x|a,b ) = b a Γ ( a ) x a-1 exp ( -bx ) 1 ( 0, ∞ ) ( x ) , with a>0 and b>0 .
Hint-2
Negative Binomial distribution x ∼ Nb ( r, θ ) has PMF: Nb ( x|r, θ ) =( r+x-1 r-1 ) θ r (1- θ ) x 1 N ( x ) with θ ∈ ( 0,1 ) , r ∈ N -{0} , and N ={0,1,2,...} .
  1. Compute the likelihood in the aforesaid Bayesian model.
  2. Show that the sampling distribution is a member of the exponential family.
  3. Specify the PDF of the conjugate prior distribution Π ( λ ) of λ , and identify the parametric family of distributions as λ ∼ Ga ( a,b ) , with a>0 , and b>0 . While you are deriving the conjugate prior distribution of λ , discuss which of the prior hyper-parameters can be considered as the `strength of the prior information and which can be considered as summarizing the prior information.
  4. Compute the PDF of the posterior distribution of λ , identify the posterior distribution as a Gamma distribution Ga ( a ˜ , b ˜ ) , and compute the posterior hyper-parameters a ˜ , and b ˜ .
  5. Compute the PMF of the predictive distribution of a future outcome y= x n+1 , identify the name of the resulting predictive distribution, and compute its parameters.
Solution.     
  1. The likelihood is f( x| λ ) = ∏ i=1 n Pn ( x i | λ ) =( ∏ i=1 n 1 x i ! ) λ ∑ i=1 n x i exp ( -n λ ) (33)
  2. The k parameter exponential family of distributions has the form Ef k ( x|u,g,h, φ , θ ,c ) =u( x ) g( θ ) exp ( ∑ j=1 k c j φ j ( θ ) h j ( x ) ) ;x ∈ X and if sampling space X does not depend on θ it is also called regular. So I just need to bring the sampling density distribution in this form. It is Pn ( x| λ ) = 1 x! λ x exp ( - λ ) 1 N ( x ) = 1 x! exp ( - λ ) exp ( x log ( λ ) ) 1 N ( x ) So Pn ( λ ) is member of the regular 1 -parameter exponential family with u( x ) = 1 x! 1 N ( x ) , g( λ ) = exp ( - λ ) , h 1 ( x ) =x, φ 1 ( λ ) = log ( λ ) , c 1 =1. The sampling space X does not depend on the uncertain parameter λ and hence it is a regular exponential family of distributions.
  3. There are two ways to derive the conjugate prior. I will present both.
    Way-1
    (Theorem in the Handout)
    The sampling distribution is member of the 1- regular exponential distribution family, as the density of the sampling density distribution Pn ( x| λ ) can be written in the form Pn ( x| λ ) =u( x ) g( λ ) exp ( ∑ j=1 k c j φ j ( λ ) h j ( x ) ) ;x ∈ X with u( x ) = 1 x! 1 N -{0} ( x ) , g( λ ) = exp ( - λ ) , h 1 ( x ) =x, φ 1 ( λ ) = log ( λ ) , c 1 =1. Since the sampling space X of the sampling distribution does not depend on the unknown parameter λ , (Theorem 20 from the Handout) the conjugate prior is π ( λ ) ∝ g( λ ) τ 0 exp ( c 1 τ 1 φ 1 ( λ ) ) (34) = exp ( - λ τ 0 ) exp ( τ 1 log ( λ ) ) = λ τ 1 exp ( - λ τ 0 ) ∝ Ga ( λ |a,b ) , for a= τ 1 +1,b= τ 0 So the conjugate prior is λ ∼ Ga ( λ |a,b ) with a>0 and b>0 .
    Way-2
    (Theorem in the Handout)
    The likelihood can be written as f( x| λ ) = ∏ i=1 n Pn ( x i | λ ) = λ ∑ i=1 n x i exp ( -n λ ) ⏟ =k( t( x ) | λ ) ( ∏ i=1 n 1 x i ! ) ⏟ = ρ ( x ) (35) where a kernel of the likelihood is k( t( x ) | λ ) = λ ∑ i=1 n x i exp ( -n λ ) , with sufficient statistics t( x ) =( n, ∑ i=1 n x i ) , and ρ ( x ) =( ∏ i=1 n 1 x i ! ) is the residual term of it. The dimensionality of the sufficient statistic t( x ) does not depend on the sample size n , and the observables are iid. Hence, (Theorem 12 in the Handout) the conjugate prior results as the aforesaid likelihood kernel from (35) where the sufficient statistics are replaced by a priori hyper-parameters τ =( τ 0 , τ 1 ) , such as π ( λ ) ∝ k( τ | λ ) = λ τ 1 exp ( - τ 0 λ ) ∝ Ga ( λ |a,b ) , for a= τ 1 +1,b= τ 0 (36) where I recognize the kernel of the Gamma distribution. So the conjugate prior is λ ∼ Ga ( a,b ) with a>0 and b>0 .
    In (34) and (36) , as strength of the prior information can be considered the parameter τ 0 (and hence b ) because it substitutes the sample size n in the likelihood (33). In (34) and (36) , as prior information summary can be considered the parameter τ 1 (and hence a ) because it substitutes the summary ∑ i=1 n x i in the likelihood (33).
  4. According to the definition, the posterior PDF can be computed via the Bayes theorem π ( λ |x ) ∝ f( x| λ ) π ( λ ) ∝ ∏ i=1 n Pn ( x i | λ ) Ga ( λ |a,b ) ∝ ( ∏ i=1 n 1 x i ! ) λ ∑ i=1 n x i exp ( -n λ ) × b a Γ ( a ) λ a-1 exp ( - λ b ) ∝ λ ∑ i=1 n x i +a-1 exp ( - λ ( n+b ) ) ∝ Ga ( λ | ∑ i=1 n x i +a,n+b ) So the posterior distribution is λ |x ∼ Ga ( a ˜ , b ˜ ) , a ˜ = ∑ i=1 n x i +a , b ˜ =n+b .
    • Alternatively, we could use the Theorem in the Lecture notes stating the properties of the Conjugate priors... I.e. λ |x ∼ Ga ( ∑ i=1 n x i +( τ 1 +1 ) ,n+( τ 0 ) ) –It is up to you...
  5. According to the definition, the predictive PMF is g( y|x ) = ∫ ( 0, ∞ ) f( y| λ ) π ( λ |x ) d λ = ∫ ( 0, ∞ ) Pn ( y| λ ) Ga ( λ | a ˜ , b ˜ ) d λ = ∫ ( 0, ∞ ) 1 y! λ y exp ( - λ ) 1 N -{0} ( y ) b ˜ a ˜ Γ ( a ˜ ) λ a ˜ -1 exp ( - λ b ˜ ) d λ = 1 y! b ˜ a ˜ Γ ( a ˜ ) 1 N -{0} ( y ) ∫ ( 0, ∞ ) λ y+ a ˜ -1 exp ( - λ ( b ˜ +1 ) ) d λ = 1 y! b ˜ a ˜ Γ ( a ˜ ) Γ ( y+ a ˜ ) ( b ˜ +1 ) y+ a ˜ 1 N -{0} ( y ) = 1 y! ( b ˜ b ˜ +1 ) a ˜ ( 1 b ˜ +1 ) y Γ ( y+ a ˜ ) Γ ( a ˜ ) 1 N -{0} ( y ) = 1 y! ( b ˜ b ˜ +1 ) a ˜ ( 1 b ˜ +1 ) y ( y+ a ˜ -1 ) ( y+ a ˜ -2 ) ⋯ ( a ˜ ) Γ ( a ˜ ) Γ ( a ˜ ) 1 N -{0} ( y ) = 1 y! ( b ˜ b ˜ +1 ) a ˜ ( 1 b ˜ +1 ) y ( y+ a ˜ -1 ) ( y+ a ˜ -2 ) ⋯ ( a ˜ ) 1 N -{0} ( y ) = 1 y! ( b ˜ b ˜ +1 ) a ˜ ( 1 b ˜ +1 ) y ( y+ a ˜ -1 ) ! ( a ˜ -1 ) ! 1 N -{0} ( y ) = ( y+ a ˜ -1 ) ! ( a ˜ -1 ) !y! ( b ˜ b ˜ +1 ) a ˜ ( 1 b ˜ +1 ) y 1 N -{0} ( y ) =( y+ a ˜ -1 a ˜ -1 )( b ˜ b ˜ +1 ) a ˜ (1- b ˜ b ˜ +1 ) y 1 N -{0} ( y ) = Nb ( y| a ˜ , b ˜ b ˜ +1 ) where a ˜ = ∑ i=1 n x i +a , b ˜ =n+b .

Exercise 53. ( ★ ★ )
Consider the Bayesian model { x i | θ ∼ IID Mu k ( θ ) ,i=1,...,n θ ∼ Π ( θ ) where θ ∈ Θ , with Θ ={ θ ∈ (0,1 ) k | ∑ j=1 k θ j =1} and X k ={x ∈ {0,1 } k | ∑ j=1 k x j =1} .
Hint-1:
Mu k denotes the Multinomial probability distribution with PMF Mu k ( x| θ ) ={ ∏ j=1 k θ j x j , if x ∈ X k 0 , otherwise
Hint-2:
Di k ( a ) denotes the Dirichlet distribution with PDF Di k ( θ |a ) ={ Γ ( ∑ j=1 k a j ) ∏ j=1 k Γ ( a j ) ∏ j=1 k θ j a j -1 , if θ ∈ Θ 0 , otherwise
  1. Derive the conjugate prior distribution for θ , and recognize that it is a Dirichlet distribution family of distributions.
  2. Verify that the prior distribution you derived above is indeed conjugate by using the definition.
Solution.  
  1.  There are two alternative ways to derive the conjugate prior here.
    1. [Way (a)] I can factorize the likelihood in a form that the likelihood kernel is a function of a sufficient statistic whose dimension is independent on the sample size n , and then derive the conjugate by substituting the sufficient statistic elements by prior hyper-parameters.
      There are k-1 independent parameters in Mu k ( θ ) because ∑ j=1 k θ j =1 . I consider as parameters ( θ 1 ,..., θ k-1 ) and the last one is a function of them as θ k =1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j .
      The likelihood is f( x 1:n | θ ) = ∏ i=1 n Mu k ( x i | θ ) = ∏ i=1 n [ ∏ j=1 k θ j x i,j ] = ∏ j=1 k θ j ∑ i=1 n x i,j = ∏ j=1 k θ j x *,j = ∏ j=1 k-1 θ j x *,j θ k x *,k where x *,j = ∑ i=1 n x i,j . So f( x 1:n | θ ) = ∏ j=1 k-1 θ j x *,j ( 1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j ) n- ∑ j=1 k-1 x *,j =(1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j ) n exp ( ∑ j=1 k-1 x *,j log ( θ j 1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j ) ) and the sufficient statistic is t n =( n, x *,1 ,..., x *,k-1 )
    2. [Way (b)] Alternatively, we can observe that the sampling space X k does not depend on the parameters. So we can show that the sampling distribution is an exponential family of distributions, identify its components, and then derive the conjugate prior.
      There are k-1 independent parameters in Mu k ( θ ) because ∑ j=1 k θ j =1 . I consider as parameters ( θ 1 ,..., θ k-1 ) and the last one is a function of them as θ k =1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j .
      It is Mu k ( x| θ ) = ∏ j=1 k θ j x j = ∏ j=1 k-1 θ j x j (1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j ) 1- ∑ j=1 k-1 x j =( 1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j ) exp ( ∑ j=1 k-1 x j log ( θ j 1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j ) ) This is the k-1 exponential family PDF with u( x ) =1; g( θ ) =( 1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j ) ; c =( 1,...,1 ) h( x ) =( x 1 ,... x k-1 ) ; φ ( θ ) =( log ( θ 1 1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j ) ,..., log ( θ k-1 1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j ) ) ,
    Then either by substituting the sufficient statistics in way (a), or by using the components of the exponential family of distributions in way (b) Let τ =( τ 0 ,..., τ k-1 ) . It is π ( θ | τ ) ∝ (1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j ) τ 0 exp ( ∑ j=1 k-1 τ j log ( θ j 1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j ) ) ∝ ∏ j=1 k-1 θ j τ j (1- ∑ j=1 k-1 θ j ) τ 0 - ∑ j=1 k-1 τ j ∝ ∏ j=1 k-1 θ j τ j θ k τ 0 - ∑ j=1 k-1 τ j Here, I recognize the Dirichlet distribution with a j = τ j for j=1,...,k-1 and a k = τ 0 - ∑ j=1 k-1 τ j .
  2. Well, the posterior is Dirichlet too. It is π ( θ | x 1:n ) ∝ ∏ i=1 n Mu k ( x i | θ ) Di k ( θ |a ) ∝ ∏ j=1 k θ j x *,j ∏ j=1 k θ j a j -1 = ∏ j=1 k θ j x j + a *,j -1 ∝ Di k ( θ | a ˜ ) where a ˜ =( a ˜ 1 ,..., a ˜ k ) , with a ˜ j = a j + x *,j for j=1,...,k . So the posterior is θ | x 1:n ∼ Di k ( a ˜ ) .

  • ϝ ( 1 ) ( α ) = d 2 d α 2 log ( Γ ( a ) )

Exercise 59. ( ★ ★ ★ )
Consider the the model of Normal linear regression where the observables are pairs ( φ i , y i ) for i=1,...,n , assumed to be modeled according to the sampling distribution y i | β , σ 2 ∼ N ( φ i ⊤ β , σ 2 ) for i=1,...,n with unknown ( β , σ 2 ) ∈ R d × R + . Namely, y| β , σ 2 ∼ N n ( Φ β ,I σ 2 ) where y=( y 1 ,... y n ) , and Φ is the design matrix. Here β is d -dimensional. Find the Jeffreys' priors for ( β , σ 2 ) .
Hint:
Recall your AMV: d d x x ⊤ Ax=2Ax , d d x ( c+Ax ) =A , and d d x ( A( x ) ) ⊤ = ( d d x A( x ) ) ⊤ .
Hint:
If y| β , σ 2 ∼ N n ( Φ β ,I σ 2 ) , then E y| β , σ 2 ∼ N n ( Φ β ,I σ 2 ) ( ( y- Φ β ) ⊤ ( y- Φ β ) ) =n σ 2 .
